en/new-here/new-here-nuevo-aqui.title: New here?
en/new-here/new-here-nuevo-aqui.content:
New here?
¿Nuevo aquí?
Having trouble connecting to the Internet?

SOLE Voltaje invites you to “tinker,” to be curious about the Internet and how it works, and to extend its reach so we can use the Internet in groups and thus change the world together!

Welcome to SOLE Voltaje! An initiative by SOLE Colombia dedicated to improving access to knowledge through community solutions for using the Internet in groups. There are three steps to start using SOLE Voltaje:

Get Inspired: Explore our thought-provoking questions, videos, and stories from the communities we’ve worked with.
Find Solutions: Discover a solution that helps increase connectivity in your place, your community, or your region. Solutions are organized into categories of signal, electricity, devices, people, and space, because using the internet in groups requires more than just connectivity.
Got Questions?: Share what you learn, write to us with your questions, join our tinkerers WhatsApp group and help build this movement for a more inclusive internet.

You also have an experience to learn what the Internet is and how it works, and an invitation to help us extend the blanket of solidarity so others can connect too: SOLE Voltaje Offline.
Our Tinkerer’s Ethics
[SOLE Colombia, 2024. Choose Auto-translate option in YouTube subtitles and your preferred language.](
  
  
?si=24JZFWWZwfVHShWp)
SOLE Colombia, 2024. Choose Auto-translate option in YouTube subtitles and your preferred language.
Have you ever wondered how the Internet reaches your home? Why we pay so much to connect or what it would be like to live disconnected? Getting connected to the Internet might seem like magic, but it’s actually information traveling around the world through servers - physical places that make it possible for you to read this right now.
For many, the “connected” world remains a mystery, either because they don’t have access or because they don’t know how it works. But here we like to question everything. We don’t let ourselves be carried away by mystery; this is a safe space to explore. Together, we can understand, question, and reinvent the future of the Internet.
SOLE Voltaje is that constant tension between what we already know and what remains to be discovered, between the need to be connected and the desire for technological freedom and autonomy. Here we develop tools, provocative ideas, inspirations, and collective learning spaces that promote the use of the Internet in groups to answer Big Questions, because we believe in another possible future for network connection: one that’s open, safe, and where we can all decide how we want to be connected -  humanely connected.
Everything you find here is the result of collaboration and knowledge from “cacharreros” —as we call them in Colombia— people who don’t accept “it doesn’t work” as an answer, people willing to solve problems, to take apart what no longer works until it works again. We want more people in the world to be encouraged to build the Internet with their own hands. You too can be an active network tinkerer!
To Change the World Together
The goal of SOLE Voltaje is to enable individuals or organizations working with people who have no access or limited access to the Internet to improve their situation in a self-managed way to the extent their own resources allow.
These resources include the amount of money they can dedicate to improving their situation, the amount of time they have to self-learn, implement and test solutions, the number of people who could accompany them on their journey, and the level of complexity of the solutions they can develop.
Over time, we hope that people in rural areas and digitally excluded communities can use and link various solutions together to finally have a permanent community space with connectivity and devices for learning, dialogue, and creating flourishing communities using the Internet.
There’s also a pedagogical purpose behind this guide to invite people to use technology, in a broad sense, for learning.
We would like to re-engage current users and invite new ones to be curious about the Internet and how it works, and how they can use it in groups to learn what they need or are interested in. That’s why, within the solutions, there’s also a concept guide of terms that teaches users technical and non-technical concepts so they can become active Internet tinkerers.
What is SOLE Colombia?
SOLE Colombia is a non-profit organization creating an equitable and beautiful future together – one Big Question at a time.
We spark the curiosity of groups of people, transforming Internet-enabled spaces into Self-Organized Learning Environments (SOLE), so we recognize our power and allow our lives and communities to blossom.
We shake the status quo by creating networks of communities that learn across boundaries and differences to bridge people and ideas towards a more vibrant shared world.
Are You Intrigued?
If you want to know more about our organization and how we’re changing the world, visit our website here.
We’re not fans of Social Media, but we share some of the things we do here:
Instagram
LinkedIn
Facebook

Translating this site
At SOLE Colombia we are mostly Spanish-speakers and have created the content to feed the Internet with usable and inspiring information in Spanish about how to solve internet connectivity challenges but also to transform the Internet itself by using it in groups. We would love for you and as many people in the world to be able to access, use, share and why not, contribute to this information.
For that we have created this “hack” to be translate the material which is a constant collaborative work-in-progress. You are also invited to participate!
This is how.
Want to use SOLE Voltaje in English or other languages?
SOLE Voltaje can be accessed in several other languages using the AI (Artificial Intelligence) tool incorporated in this Notion platform. The AI tool when we wrote this page in 2024 allowed to translate to 15 languages:
English
Korean
Japanese
French
Spanish
Portuguese
Chinese (simplified)
Chinese (traditional)
Dutch
Russian
German
Italian
Indonesian
Filipino
Vietnamese
How to translate using Notion AI?
We have created a “hack” which is using our paid user to login to the Notion platform and creating an open email address which you can visit to be able to get the verification code necessary to Log In. Install Kiwix on your Raspberry Pi
Welcome
Hi! I’m Gabriel, and I’m an artist. I love technology and I’m one of the first gadget makers at SOLE Colombia.
What does it mean to install a pocket Wikipedia?
Wikipedia is a collaboratively built encyclopedia. Many people contribute their knowledge and expertise to this practically universal repository of information. Bringing all of Wikipedia’s content to a device allows you to have offline access to a wealth of information with which you can learn many things.
If you share this information through an internal network with your Raspberry Pi, you can enable many people to learn with you too. That’s what we want at SOLE Colombia: for people to discover how to take the Internet to the next level: as a group. Learn more about SOLE at www.solecolombia.org to learn how communities are creating an equitable and beautiful future, together, one Big Question at a time.
What’s it for?
This recipe is part of a series of useful things you can do with your [Raspberry Pi](sole-doc.tiddlyhost.com/#Raspberry Pi). With a little work, you can set up a small pocket internet connection and turn it into a portable wireless hotspot. We can continue adding things to our Pi to make it a powerful mobile device, containing enough information to, among other things, use SOLE in places where there’s no constant internet access. In the following steps, we’ll put Wikipedia on our Pi so we can consult it whenever we need to.
What do you need?

A Raspberry Pi
A computer.
Internet connection.
A friend to talk to while you download everything you need.

What do you need?

A Raspberry Pi
A computer.
Internet connection.
A friend to talk to while you download everything you need.

How to do it?


Moment 1: Connect to your Pi
First, make sure you have a working Raspberry Pi. If you need help with this, check out the recipe for A Small Pocket Internet, where we show you how to get started with this device. Once you have your system up and running, connect to your Pi via a Terminal by starting an SSH connection. Make sure you have an internet connection to continue with the following steps.


Step 2: Download what you need


The Kiwix server
  





Moment 2: Descarga lo necesario


El servidor Kiwix
The first component we are going to download is the application that will allow us to serve the compressed Wikipedia file, so that we can access it from our local network.
  
On the Kiwix download page, copy the link titled GNU/Linux ARM (32-bit). Then, to download the file to your Pi, type the following into your terminal:
wget download.kiwix.org/release/kiwix-tools/kiwix-tools_linux-armhf.tar.gz



The compressed Wikipedia
  
Now, let’s download the compressed Wikipedia file. On the Kiwix contents page, find the version of Wikipedia that best suits your needs. We recommend downloading the 3.3GB version, which has enough information to do SOLE.
Click the download button. Then copy the link to the direct icon and type this into your terminal:
wget download.kiwix.org/zim/wikipedia/wikipedia_es_all_mini_2022-11.zim

Please wait patiently for the process to complete.




Moment 3: Now, we install everything


First the Kiwix server
  
Installing the Kiwix server is very simple; it only takes two steps:

Unzip the file you just downloaded with the following command:

tar -zxvf kiwix-tools_linux-armhf.tar.gz


  


We move the files to a system directory where the executable files are located:
sudo mv kiwix-tools_linux-armhf-3.3.0-1/* /usr/local/bin





Now, the Wikipedia archive
  
Installing the .zim file involves moving it to another directory on your system so that the Kiwix server can easily find it:
sudo mv wikipedia_es_all_mini_2022-11.zim  /var/local/





Moment 4: Let’s create a service
  
A service in Linux-like systems allows us to start, stop, and restart programs that run constantly on our operating system. Let’s create a file with the service configuration so that the Kiwix server is automatically launched when the Pi boots.
First we create the file:
sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/kiwix.service

and inside we write the following:
[Unit]
Description=Kiwix Service
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
User=root
Group=root
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/kiwix-serve /var/local/wikipedia_es_all_mini_2022-11.zim -p 8080
Restart=always
RestartSec=3

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

We save the changes and we can continue with the recipe.


Step 5: We start our server
  
The final step is to enable the new service and start it. With these two lines, the Kiwix server will start automatically every time we turn on our Pi.
sudo systemctl enable kiwix
sudo systemctl start kiwix



Moment 5: We test that everything works
  
And now… the moment we’ve been waiting for!! Let’s visit our pocket Wikipedia. In the browser of your computer or phone connected to the local network, navigate to the address solevoltaje.local:8080 . Once it loads, you can browse all the information we just downloaded :D


How do you know if this solution works?
You’ve successfully filled your Pi with information! You now have a copy of the world’s largest encyclopedia on a portable device. If you follow the recipes in this series, you can have a device that your community can connect to, search for answers to the Big Questions they have to solve, or so you can learn together.
Why might this solution work?
You’ll now be able to search your portable Wikipedia! But… it’s a reduced version, and there are many other things you could find, if you have a stable internet connection. The great thing about this recipe is that you can have Wikipedia, take it with you to many places, and allow communities to connect to your Raspberry Pi!

Buying and setting up an electricity generation system with a bicycle










Welcome
Hi, I’m Nicolas. I’m what you call a tinkerer. I’m an engineer and I’m interested in how things work. I enjoy assembling and disassembling devices to find out how they work and I also enjoy finding out how we can use the resources available in the community.
What is a bicigenerador?
A bicycle generator is a system that converts the mechanical energy of a bicycle into electrical energy. Basically, it transforms the pedaling motion into electricity, allowing it to generate energy for different purposes, such as charging electronic devices or even powering lighting systems. (Source: ecologismos.com/es-bicigenerador/
What is it for?
This solution is a step-by-step explanation of how to buy, and assemble, a bicycle power supply system. We calculated it to run a computer and a router for 3 hours, which is how long a SOLE session usually lasts.
What do you need?

Money to buy batteries, cables, a power inverter and a controller.
Power to pedal.
An old bicycle.
Care and a lot of encouragement to assemble the system.
Support to fix the bicycle.

How to do it?


Moment 1: Calculate the energy consumption
Read the energy consumption I need. In this case we need to power a laptop and a router for 3 hours. This will define the capacity that our system must have and the amount of hours we must pedal to be able to generate the necessary electricity.

A laptop consumes 120W/h
A router consumes 15W/h

Now, we must calculate the necessary energy expenditure for the system. You can check this information on the back of the devices or on the chargers of the devices. For a SOLE, for example, 3 hours are needed:

Laptop: 120W/h of consumption for 3 hours is 360W.
Router: 15W/h of consumption for 3 hours is 45W.

The result of the sum of these two is 405W, in 3 hours. If we divide 405/3h, we have 135 W/h.
The bike machine will be able to generate up to 200 watts/hour, pedaling at medium speed and up to 400 watts/hour at high speed.
  


Moment 2: Estimate the characteristics of the complementary equipment.
Remember that to assemble any power generation system you need these components:


An electricity generator.
It is any device capable of capturing and transforming some type of energy (mechanical, solar, thermal, hydraulic, chemical) into electrical energy. In this case, it is the bicycle combined with an electric motor and a static support, but we can also think of a gasoline generator, a solar panel, a Pelton turbine, a wind turbine, etc.
  
  
  


A charge controller
Its function is to regulate the flow of energy from the motor to the batteries, it controls both the intensity and the voltage. The purpose of this is to ensure that the recharge is in optimal conditions, does not damage the batteries and extends their useful life.
  


A battery
Stores the energy generated in the form of chemical energy and then releases it as direct current in a controlled manner.
  


A power inverter
Converts the direct current coming out of the battery to alternating current to be able to connect our equipment.
  


Solar cable and accessories
It is a sufficiently robust electrical cable to be able to transmit the electrical energy that we generate. In addition, we can buy some plastic connectors that help to make the connections more robust and do not disconnect easily.
  
As I note, here we can use all the same complementary assembly system for a solar panel system. For this reason we will make the calculations of the equipment as if they were for neutral solar panel system, since they will have the same capacity.




Moment 3: How to estimate the characteristics of a battery?
We had talked about an energy consumption of 405W in 3 hours or 135 W/h. In addition to the total daily consumption, we need:

Days of autonomy (days): This refers to, the days of use, if used every day the days of autonomy is 5 or more days, and only used on weekends we have 1 or 2 days. For our SOLE case we are going to put day and a half, 1.5.
The depth of discharge (Pd): Gel or AGM batteries this value is 70%. In open lead batteries it is 50%.
Voltage of the battery (V): This we choose it, as our devices are of 12V, it will be of this value.
Losses for temperature and yield: It will be assumed that it is 15%.

To calculate the capacity of the battery in Ampere-hours (ah) we use the following formula. Ah= 1.15*(Wh/díadías) /(PdV)=1.15*(135*21.5)/(70%*12)=27.72Ah. This is the minimum capacity needed, so we decided to buy a 12V and 35Ah battery.
  


Moment 4: How to estimate the characteristics of a controller?
For this we have to calculate the input current and the output current of the controller, according to these two equations:

To calculate the input current we just have to multiply 3 values: *1.25: A safety factor of 1.25 this is done to calculate with 25% more than necessary to avoid errors due to a very tight calculation. It is a common practice in engineering to oversize the calculations for safety parameters in case of failure. *Imod,sc: Unit current of the PV panel under short circuit conditions, can be found at the back of the panel. For this case it is 2.32 A.
  

Np: number of panels in series. For this case it is 2.

Calculating we have: IInput= 1.25*2.32 A.*2 = 5.8 A To calculate the output current we have to add, multiply and divide the following values:

1.25: A safety factor of 1.25 this is done to calculate with 25% more than necessary to avoid errors due to a very tight calculation. It is a common practice in engineering to oversize calculations for safety parameters in case of failure.
Pdc: Power discharge in direct current, it is the sum of the current of the devices that we are going to connect and that work with direct current. In this case we do not have any, so it is 0.
Pac: Power of loads in alternating current, it is the sum of the current of the devices that we are going to connect and that work with alternating current. In this case a laptop consumes 120W/h and a router consumes 15W/h, for a total of 135 W/h.
Ninv: Inverter efficiency, around 90-95%.
Vbat: Battery voltage. This can be read from the selected battery. For this case it is 12V.

Calculating we have: Isalide= 1.25*(0+(120+15)/0.95)/12=14.80 A Finally we just need to round up our calculations. Input=5.8≃6A Isalide=14.80≃15A So our controller should support at least an input current of 6A and an output current of 15A. So we bought one of 20A and a voltage of 12/24V (it switches automatically).
  


Moment 5: How to estimate the characteristics of an inverter?
As we are going to use low consumption equipment, the inverter to be used is a modified wave inverter. The calculation is made by oversizing 25% more than our total consumption. Remember that the total consumption is 405W. So I=V1.25=4051.25=506.25 W This must be the minimum capacity of the inverter. In our case we bought one of 750W.


Moment 6: How to know which cable to buy?
Usually solar cables are sized using the term AWG (American Wire Gauges) in order to estimate the gauge scale. But for solar cables the gauge is usually specified by its section or area in mm². Thus in Colombia we can find from 2.5mm² to 16mm² depending on the manufacturer.
  
It must be chosen in relation to the current to be transported. In this case, we will not carry more than 20A, so a 14 AGW cable, i.e. 2.5 mm2, is fine. As far as connectors are concerned in our case, we will buy two, but it will depend on the configuration that each one of us will put together.


Moment 7: Find a supplier
Find a supplier of electrical supplies and quote for this equipment. In addition, you can consult with them to find out if the calculations you made are correct or if there is another way to optimize your power generation system. Compare the costs between different suppliers and buy taking into account the confidence in the place, warranty and prices.


How to use it?


Precautions
Now that we have the motor, the bike, the battery, the inverter, we must remember that the last thing to count is the battery.
A safety warning: We should only connect one of the poles in time, so that we do not take the current. It is good to work with rubber gloves since it insulates us with respect to a possible electrocution. We recommend you to read the section Basic precautions when working with electricity.


Connecting the circuit
The motor has a negative and a positive pole, it is important to identify which one is which to build the new circuit. Generally the positive is represented by red and the negative by black. In the case of the connection of a motor you must identify which way it turns when it is connected in one way or another, the motor must be connected in such a way that it turns in the same direction that the bicycle will turn, that is to say “forward”. Remember that for this solution what we are doing is to reverse the operation of a motor, that is, when the motor rotates, an electromagnetic field will be created which will interact with the permanent magnets of the electric motor, generating an electric current.
  
Now, connect the negative and positive wires coming out of the motor to the controller, it is clearly marked on the controller where each wire is connected. Then cut two wires and strip their ends to make the connection to the battery.
  
Now connect these wires coming out of the controller to the battery, respecting the positive and negative connection.
  
When you have connected them, join the wires from the inverter to the battery and this is how you will have your system ready. Once the whole system is assembled you will be able to connect the computer or router to the inverter.
  


How to know if this solution works?
With this solution you will have electricity to power your SOLE, remember that this solution is calculated with the example of the power consumption of a router and a computer. If you want to have permanent electricity for more equipment you should make your own calculations.
Why would this solution work?
This solution only allows to have energy independence of a router and a laptop for 3 hours at night, in case the panel has captured sunlight during the day. If you are using it during the day, this time can be extended, since the panel will be constantly charging and when you use the electrical devices it discharges.

Improve your mobile network connection

Audio reading of the solution
You can listen to this audio lecture while developing this solution.
[ Construye una antena 3G casera.mp3](Construye una antena 3G casera 12a2bd68c5b68081835bedffa7d7de18/_Construye_una_antena_3G_casera.mp3)
Welcome
Hi, I’m Nicolas. Like you, I have been progressively learning how to improve my connectivity. I’m not an expert on the subject, but through internet searches, tutorials and, above all, trial and error, I’ve learned a lot and have assembled functional solutions. ****
What is building a homemade 3G antenna?
In this particular solution we will build an antenna with easily accessible materials that will allow to increase the 3G and 4G signal strength of a cell phone or a MiFi modem.
Below, you will find an instruction manual that tries to be as precise and detailed as possible so that you can feel accompanied and safe as you progress in this hack.
The estimated construction time is about 6 to 7 hours and consists of 8 moments, but do not panic, you can make the antenna a few at a time and with the help of other people, remember that in SOLE Voltage we want to promote the collective use of the internet. We also made a video with the same steps in case it makes it easier for you to follow the instruction by this means.

What is it for?
In this recipe, we are going to build a homemade antenna prepared to receive waves that carry the 4G signal - those of mobile Internet - in order to improve the quality of the connection from your phone, or a shared modem(MiFi).
What do you need?


Materials

3 mm thick aluminum rod (it has to be exactly 3 mm).
50 cm of plastic conduit.
Fast drying epoxy glue.
Good wave.
10 mt of coaxial cable.
2 presses or clamps.
2 pressure clamps.
20 cm of copper wire.
A ruler (even better if you have a caliper, it allows you to be more accurate).
Reamer (If you get an electric polisher with a fine cutting disc, you will save a lot of time).
High precision.
Fine point indelible marker.
Pencil.
Soldering iron, tin, flux.
Tweezers and pliers (the latter is optional).
Metallic file.
Work table with good lighting.
Plastic ties.
Pole to mount the antenna (a bamboo as long as possible or a rigid rod of any material).
Scalpel, cutter.
Wire stripper (optional).
Cell phone or shared modem (MiFi).




How to do it?


Step 0: Before starting, some recommendations for your care.
This solution has an intermediate level of difficulty and involves the use of some tools that can cause accidents if you are not careful. For this reason it is important to take into account the following recommendations:

When using any cutting element place it in such a way that the cutting force is directed away from your body and not towards it.
Keep pets or children away from the work area, mainly because of the easy contact with a hot soldering iron.
Before cutting, make sure that the presses, clamps or clamps that hold the material do not allow the slightest movement of the material when applying any type of force.
When using solder and epoxy glue, be especially careful not to damage the work surface.
Do not use the antenna during thunderstorms since the antenna can be a lightning rod that attracts lightning to your environment.



Step 1: Check the materials
Before starting, check and have at hand all the necessary elements to work with. In case you don’t know any of the materials you can check the photo showing the materials listed. Purchases can be made at the nearest hardware store, the materials are common, so it should not be a problem to find them. Perhaps, the most important item on the list is the aluminum rod and it may be a little harder to get, sometimes you can find items made with this type of rod in the metal brackets they sell in stores that bring many Chinese products. At SOLE Voltage we have used different metals: copper, welding rods and galvanized wire. We opted to buy a 3mm steel welding rod. If you can’t find aluminum in the hardware store, you can ask for other options, the important thing is that its diameter is as close as possible to 3mm or 1/8 of an inch.
Now organize the workspace, have these instructions at hand and divide the tasks among the participants of the process: someone can be in charge of measuring, others of cutting, ordering and gluing.


Step 2: Understand the schematic
Here is the final schematic and some of the parts of the assembly to give you a better understanding of the final assembly.
  


Step 3: Measuring, cutting and marking
It’s time to get started! Here we get down to work, you must cut each of the 10 elements that make up the antenna. With the help of the caliper (or ruler), you have to mark the length of each one and cut them with the saw or the polishing machine. It is recommended that you cut one or half a millimeter extra and finish adjusting their length by filing the edges with the metal file. Below is a list of the length of the 10 metal rods that you must cut, in the world of antennas these have their specific names (director, reflector and dipole) related to the function they serve.
  
This is the list of cuts that are necessary:


Reflector: 8.0 cm


Dipole: 18 cm (This should be the length of the element, the bent rod should be exactly 7.6 cm, for now just cut the rod to this length).


Director #1: 7.6 cm


Director #2: 7.5 cm


Director #3: 7.4 cm


Director #4: 7.4 cm


Director #5: 7.3 cm


Director #6: 7.3 cm


Director #7: 7.2 cm


Director #8: 7.2 cm




📏 Remember that 10 mm=1 cm
<img src="/assets\images\A pocket Wikipedia in your RaspberryPi 1a42bd68c5b680289571fc002238a69a\image 4-800w.webp" alt="image.png" srcset="/assets\images\A pocket Wikipedia in your RaspberryPi 1a42bd68c5b680289571fc002238a69a\image 4-400w.webp 400w, /assets\images\A pocket Wikipedia in your RaspberryPi 1a42bd68c5b680289571fc002238a69a\image 4-800w.webp 800w, /assets\images\A pocket Wikipedia in your RaspberryPi 1a42bd68c5b680289571fc002238a69a\image 4-1200w.webp 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 400px, (max-width: 1200px) 800px, 1200px" loading="lazy" />

It is important to mark each of the cuts with a tape, as shown in the photo, so that the next step is easier to do.

<img src="/assets\images\A pocket Wikipedia in your RaspberryPi 1a42bd68c5b680289571fc002238a69a\image 5-800w.webp" alt="image.png" srcset="/assets\images\A pocket Wikipedia in your RaspberryPi 1a42bd68c5b680289571fc002238a69a\image 5-400w.webp 400w, /assets\images\A pocket Wikipedia in your RaspberryPi 1a42bd68c5b680289571fc002238a69a\image 5-800w.webp 800w, /assets\images\A pocket Wikipedia in your RaspberryPi 1a42bd68c5b680289571fc002238a69a\image 5-1200w.webp 1200w" sizes="(max-width: 600px) 400px, (max-width: 1200px) 800px, 1200px" loading="lazy" />



Step 4: Bend the dipole
The dipole is an element bent in the shape of a “C”. Its overall length should be 7.6 cm, but the rod should be a little longer (about 18.0 cm). Making this piece is a trial and error task. In my case I have found it helpful to slowly bend the rod against a 2 cm diameter circular tube to give it the curvature.
  


Step 5: Assembling the antenna
We are already half way through the process. Don’t be discouraged! ****Now it’s time to assemble the elements on the channel. This can be replaced by wood or any other material at hand, as long as it does not conduct electricity.
  
On the surface of the trough, the following distances must be marked, over which each of the rod cuts made in the previous step will be placed.

Reflector: 1.0 cm
Dipole: 5.0 cm
Director #1: 6.2 cm
Director #2: 9.2 cm
Director #3: 12.8 cm
Director #4: 17.0 cm
Director #5: 21.7 cm
Director #6: 26.7 cm
Director #7: 31.9 cm
Director #8: 37.4 cm

Once you have marked the lines you can glue each of the rods with the epoxy glue on the trough, however, we have found that this configuration is very fragile and makes our antenna not last very long. For this reason we found a better way to attach the rods to the trough. For this we can use the hot soldering iron that with its fine tip can easily go through the plastic, then with this tool we will pierce the sides until it has a sufficient diameter to pass the rod. Take advantage of as soon as the plastic is hot just pierce it to pass the rod and make sure it has the right diameter. This should be done on both sides of the gutter so that the rod can pass through from side to side.
  
Once you have finished drilling the 20 holes, you must disassemble the trough and use the metal file to remove the burrs from the plastic to allow the rods to enter easily.
  
Now, before positioning each of the rods we must make a small cut to facilitate the entry of the dipole, for this we must disassemble the channel and with the saw to make a vertical cut so that it crosses the sides of the second measure (5.0 cm) to reach the hole that we opened with the soldering iron.
  
Once the dipole is embedded we can insert the other rods according to the order already mentioned.
  
s
A little epoxy glue can be added on the rod to ensure that the elements are well adhered to the trough. Wait the necessary time for the glue to dry before continuing to attach the wire to your new antenna.
  


Step 6: Prepare the cable
While the glue is drying, you can proceed with the preparation of the
coaxial cable
(you can review the previous post to understand how a coaxial cable is formed before disassembling it).
  
To do this part you can use a wire stripper or a cutter to separate each layer of the cable, you must be careful in the cut to avoid breaking the first layer which is a wire mesh. Thus, at one end you have to leave free the copper wire and the cable mesh. You can carefully separate the mesh and then braid it again.
  
At the other end, with the copper wire, make a wave, which will be the element that comes into contact with the phone, or Mifi, to improve the signal.
  


Step 7: Solder the dipole
This is one of the most careful steps, after this we move on to the assembly. Remember that the dipole is one of the fundamental components of the antenna, this must be soldered to the end of the coaxial cable that we separated in the mesh and the copper wire, and this in turn is connected with a copper wire bridging each end of the dipole. First we make the bridge with the copper wire as shown in the image, where each end is braided and then soldered.
  
Once we have the copper wire soldered to the two ends of the coaxial we can attach it to the dipole, for this we can first tighten it a little with the pliers and then proceed to solder.
  
Remember that the dipole must be perpendicular to the trough, so to avoid sudden movements of the cable that change this position we must secure the cable with plastic ties.
  


Step 8: Final assembly
Finally we are done, now you can assemble and install the antenna! To do this, make sure it is well adjusted with plastic ties at the top of the pole, the antenna should be oriented so that the dipole is as close as possible to the pole.
  
Remember also to tie the cable to the pole, so that it does not come loose from the welding points on the antenna. Now, raise the pole and make sure that the position of the antenna is facing the direction of the nearest cell tower.
Now, on the other end of the cable, place your cell phone so that the copper coil is touching the back of the device.
  
  
The antenna addressing process must be done slowly and carefully, the waves are very sensitive to movement. First, they can establish the 0 position and, from there, they can be rotated to the right or left in small intervals. After each movement, you can check the quality of connection to the cellular network from the “Settings” screen of the phone. This is a number expressed in decibels (Db), the higher it is, the lower the signal quality. You can also do this by looking at the strength of the signal icon on the top of the cell phone. The challenge is to find the place where the number of decibels is lower or where the signal strength icon is higher.
  
Now, you can proceed to secure the pole in this position and that’s it, let’s go sailing!



Recommendations for points of possible difficulty
If you are using the solder and it keeps slipping, it must be that the tin solder you possibly bought is not compatible with the metal of the rods you are using, so we recommend you to look for another solder or try to make contact between the wire and the rod by tightening them well by means of a wire. Normally each metal is related to a solder of the same metal (steel to steel solder, tin to tin solder).
How do we know if this solution works?
We can know if this solution works by doing speed tests, searching with these words some page on the Internet, this will give you as a result the amount of Megabits per second (Mb/s) both in downloading and uploading information. On the other hand you can measure the quality of the connection to the network using decibels (Db), this is explained in the “Final Assembly” section above. To be able to contrast you can make measurements with and without the antenna to recognize how much the signal improves with this device.
Why would this solution work?
This solution can work to improve the connectivity conditions temporarily.  This is because the antenna will serve as an amplifier of the emission and reception wave of your devices.

A powerful message can change the world, connect with your purpose
Welcome
Hello! I’m Manu, the storyteller of SOLE Colombia and today I want to talk to you about the power of a message.
If you are here it’s because you want to learn how you can mobilize others with your cause and build a powerful message. Shall we do it together?
What is creating a powerful message?
In this solution, we are going to dive into a very special methodology in the world of storytelling: the Golden Circle, created by Simon Sinek. We will use this step-by-step methodology to help you develop a clear and powerful message.
Through the three fundamental questions posed by Sinek, I will guide you to unravel the message behind your cause. When you convene others with a clear and powerful message you make them feel deeply connected to you.
Get ready because this is going to be exciting!
What’s the point?
Creating a powerful, purpose-driven message means connecting emotionally with your audience and inspiring them to take action. It serves to inspire others, appeals to their emotions and values creating a deeper and more meaningful connection. You will create a more coherent and consistent communication.
What do you need?

Paper.
Stylus/Pencil or any digital tool.
And, of course, enthusiasm.

How to do it?
[Vídeo sin título ‐ Hecho con Clipchamp (5).mp4](Crea un mensaje potente 12a2bd68c5b680c198cee71d7d6322e7/Vdeo_sin_ttulo__Hecho_con_Clipchamp_(5).mp4)


Moment 1: Start with the what
What do you do or want to do, what do you want to share or offer to the world? That is the “what” of your message. Starting with the what will help you to glimpse more easily your why.
Here your ideas take shape and become tangible actions: a product, a service or an offer.
Activity: To discover it, I invite you to write down on a blank sheet of paper what you are doing or offering in tangible terms… A SOLE? an activity? a product?
If you still have doubts, use the examples to start your golden circle. Courage!
[Vídeo sin título ‐ Hecho con Clipchamp (6).mp4](Crea un mensaje potente 12a2bd68c5b680c198cee71d7d6322e7/Vdeo_sin_ttulo__Hecho_con_Clipchamp_(6).mp4)


Moment 2: Define the how
We are on the right track! Now that you know the flame that moves you, it’s time to think about how to fan it and take your message to the world. What strategies, actions or methods will you use to make your why shine?
It’s time to determine the methods and processes you will use to bring your “what” to life. For this step you need to know how you do what you do to fulfill your motivation. Think about whether it is a format that makes you unique, a product that no one else has thought of, or an original service you offer. What matters here are the qualities
Activity:

Write on a sheet of paper a list of the activities you do to fulfill your “what” and select the ones you find most relevant.
Now put them all in the same place and write your how.

See how I did it to guide you:
[Vídeo sin título ‐ Hecho con Clipchamp (7).mp4](Crea un mensaje potente 12a2bd68c5b680c198cee71d7d6322e7/Vdeo_sin_ttulo__Hecho_con_Clipchamp_(7).mp4)


Moment 3: Shape your why.
Finally, you need to be clear about the fundamental purpose behind the message. What is the inspiring reason that motivates you?
When we are clear about our “why”, we create an emotional bond with our audience, awakening their interest and commitment from a deeper level.
Activity: To discover the why of your message, grab a blank sheet of paper and write down what first comes to mind. Don’t hesitate too long. It’s okay if it’s just a few words, little by little it will take shape 😉That’s my why:
[Vídeo sin título ‐ Hecho con Clipchamp (8).mp4](Crea un mensaje potente 12a2bd68c5b680c198cee71d7d6322e7/Vdeo_sin_ttulo__Hecho_con_Clipchamp_(8).mp4)
Tip: Think about what it is that motivates you to do what you’re doing, and you’ll see that little by little the words will appear.


How do you know if this solution works?
There you have it, you have your why ready and so your message is much more powerful. Now you can have more clarity when you want to infect others with your purpose or that of your product. Remember, the most important thing is that it is authentic, that it reflects your essence and that it makes you feel identified.
Now is your time to shine! Go ahead, conquer the world with your message! 🚀 Show us in the comments what your Golden Circle looks like!
Why might this solution work?
Your message should reflect your purpose, that thing that drives you to action. It must be authentic and resonate with the people who hear you.
Aligning your messages and your actions with your purpose makes your communication coherent, take care of it. If your message is genuine, authentic and reflects your true passion, you will be honoring your why.
It is very important that your message creates an emotional connection with whoever receives it, remember that only when we create emotional bonds with others, we get the words to truly touch the hearts of others.
Remember! the goal of a powerful message is to motivate others to do something, to take action and follow you, to inspire, connect and motivate them to follow your vision.

In communication, the audience rules
Welcome
Hello! 😊
I’m Manu, the storyteller of SOLE Colombia. In all the stories I tell, I always keep in mind to whom I am addressing what I want to say… have you ever wondered how to really reach the people who will value your message the most, or who will participate in your projects?
In this solution we are going to discover your audience together, are you ready?
What is discovering your audience?
Knowing your audience means understanding in depth who are the people you are targeting with your content. When you know your audience, you can focus your efforts where you know they will have an impact. What’s the point of sending an email if you want to invite your family?
Knowing your audience, you know by heart the shortest way to get straight to the heart of your people, and connect with the right people, so that your message reaches further.
What is it good for?
When you know who you are targeting and know them well, it allows you to tailor your message, tone and communication style to resonate with the people you are targeting and what you say to them will resonate with them.
You will create content that is more relevant to those people, appropriate to their interests and needs, useful, interesting and valuable to them… you will certainly improve the way they perceive you, but, most importantly, you will be able to create genuine and authentic connections because your message will go straight to their hearts.
What do you need?

Paper
Stylus/Pencil
Enthusiasm
Cell phone or computer (for writing and carrying out the activities)

How to do it?


Moment 1: Define your ‘target audience’ in detail
Before you start, clearly establish who are the people you want to reach with your message or call… Think about the key characteristics of the people you want to reach.
Take out your pencil or pen and answer on a sheet of paper:

What are the interests, needs or challenges of your audience?
What kind of people would be most interested in what you have to offer?

See how I did with this exercise:
[Ilustración_sin_título(12).mp4](Descubre a tu audiencia 12a2bd68c5b6804396abdf10642ab64d/Ilustracion_sin_titulo(12).mp4)


Moment 2: Create your personas, dig deep to create your ideal person.
Taking into account the answer to the questions below, create detailed profiles of your target audience. This will help you visualize and better understand who you are targeting and what motivates them.

Discover their characteristics: write down the basic qualities of your ideal audience, such as age, gender, geographic location, education level, etc.
Interests and motivations: describe what motivates or interests these people, what are they looking for or need?
Behaviors and preferences: where do they usually spend their time, what type of content do they consume or what activities do they enjoy?
Challenges: what are the things that prevent them from getting to where they want to go or where you want to invite them? what are the challenges they face?

When you have completed this exercise it will be easier to visualize your ideal audience. See how I did it:
[Ilustración_sin_título(13).mp4](Descubre a tu audiencia 12a2bd68c5b6804396abdf10642ab64d/Ilustracion_sin_titulo(13).mp4)


Moment 3: Observe and listen to your people, look for answers.
Now that you have a clear idea of who your potential participants are, it’s time to observe and listen.

Start interacting with your potential audience through surveys, interviews or simply observing their interactions online.
Note any responses, comments or patterns that will help you better understand their needs and preferences and disseminate your message, taking into account their reactions or behaviors.



How do you know if this solution works?
It is very important that you come up with ways to analyze the way your audience lets you know that you are reaching them. How can you know?
Observe: how do the people who interact with your messages behave? Talk to them directly, invent easy ways to collect data about their experiences, opinions, expectations… you can design a survey or form to get more data and treat it statistically.
Looking for patterns, trends and motivations can lead you to more qualitative analysis, where you can find more complex and interesting explanations about your audience.
It’s exciting to find the best way to communicate with the people you want to reach! Ask yourself questions about them constantly, so you can communicate better and better.
Is it working for you, write to tell me about it!
Why might this solution work?
Many times, as you get better at defining your audience, you realize that there are subgroups that you want to approach and, necessarily, you have to do it in a different way.
For example, in SOLE Colombia we have a very large Community, in which there are different ‘characters’ to whom we speak. We can’t talk to the Abuelitas in the same way we talk to the Cacharreros, because it simply wouldn’t work. The content we create, aims to accommodate all of them, but to address specific messages to each group, building community from the affection we give to each group.
We think a lot about the ways of communicating and the audiences we discover, that’s what we do. Continually experimenting. Adapting to the findings. And doing it all over again. Many times.
It’s fun!

Share your pocket internet
Welcome
Hi, I’m Gabriel. I’m an artist. Digital devices, how they work and the way we humans interact with them, are interesting to me. I consider myself a tinkerer and I invite you, if you want, to be one too.
I wrote the Raspberry Pi: Una pequeña Internet de bolsillo solution so you could set it up, and now I’ll walk you through how to share your device’s signal with other people or other devices.
What is sharing the internet on your RasperryPi?
Having a computer the size of a credit card, being able to connect it to the Internet and, in addition, being able to share that connection with the other computers you have to do SOLE, is to open the doors to the largest library in the world!
It is to turn any space into a Self-Organized Learning Environment where you can open the doors to the creativity to solve the challenges, complex or simple, of your community… UNBELIEVABLE!
To make SOLE there are only three fundamental things: people, a few computers with internet connection and Big Questions.
What is it for?
With this recipe you can turn your Raspberry Pi into a portable Router, so that your community can connect wirelessly and access the information hosted there, and, if you have a wired Internet connection, you can share it too.
What do you need?

A Raspberry Pi
A computer
Internet connection - you can check the solution ¿Cómo saber qué tipo de señal de Internet tienes? to make sure what kind of connection you have, and if you have it active.
A lot of patience

How to do it?


Step 1: Connect to your Pi

First of all, make sure you have a working Raspberry Pi. If you need help for this, check the recipe **Rasperry Pi: A small pocket Internet** where we tell you how to get started with this device.
Once you have your system up and running, connect to your Rasperry Pi via Terminal by initiating an SSH connection.
Make sure you have an Internet connection to be able to continue with the following steps.



Step 2: Upgrade your Raspberry Pi system
  
The first step is to perform an update of the entire [system](../../Conceptorio 12a2bd68c5b6808baf3be5e67cddb488/Conceptorio 1624106bff984c4590342afeae3e5e0d/Sistema informático (SI)%20Information%20system%20(IS)%202382bd68c5b680609579f5e5eb9f0836.md), to ensure that we have the latest versions of the programs running on our Pi.
To do this, just type in the terminal:
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade

The system will warn us which packages need to be updated. To continue with the process, we must accept, typing y and pressing the enter key.


Moment 3: Install the necessary software
  
Next, we must install two programs on our Pi:
sudo apt install -y hostapd dnsmasq

This command will install hostapd which is a utility that allows us to use the wireless of our Pi as a wireless access point and dnsmasq which will allow us to configure a DNS and DHCP server to allow users to connect to the server and can have the necessary network configurations to access it.


Step 4: Configure a static IP


Disable the wireless interface
  
In this step we will configure a static IP address on the wireless interface of our PI. It is important that you are not connected wirelessly to the Pi, because during the following steps the wireless communication will be suspended. So, make sure you are connected via a cable, or have a display and keyboard connected directly to the Pi to continue.
The network settings on the Pi are being handled by the dhpcd program, which is responsible for requesting and assigning the necessary IP addresses for the available network interfaces. At this point, we need to tell this program to ignore the wireless interface. To do this, we have to edit the configuration file:
sudo nano /etc/dhcpcd.conf

… and at the end of it, add this line:
denyinterfaces wlan0

To exit and save the changes we press ctrl + x followed by y when it asks us.


Assign a static IP
  
Now we must assign to the wlan0 interface a static IP address in another range different from that of our wired network. Let’s edit the file:
sudo nano /etc/network/interfaces

Don’t be afraid. It looks complex, but, if you have come this far, you are not far away. Add the following at the end:
allow-hotplug wlan0
iface wlan0 inet static
    address 192.168.10.1
    netmask 255.255.255.0
    network 192.168.10.0
    broadcast 192.168.10.255

What we are doing is configuring this interface to have the IP 192.168.10.1.
To exit and save the changes, press ctrl + x followed by y when prompted.




Moment 5: Configuring our wireless access point
  
It is time to tell hostapd how to operate. We will tell it to broadcast the network name(SSID) and to operate on a specific channel. We will put these settings in the file :
sudo nano /etc/hostapd/hostapd.conf

… where we add the following data:
interface=wlan0
driver=nl80211
ssid=SOLEVOLTAJE
hw_mode=g
channel=11
ieee80211n=1
wmm_enabled=1
ht_capab=[HT40][SHORT-GI-20][DSSS_CCK-40]
macaddr_acl=0
auth_algs=1
ignore_broadcast_ssid=0
wpa=2
wpa_key_mgmt=WPA-PSK
wpa_passphrase=LACONTRASENADEACCESO
rsn_pairwise=CCMP

Here you can change some things:

The name of the network: this is configured in the line ssid= in our example, the network will be called SOLEVOLTAJE.
The channel: channel=11 is saying that we are going to operate on channel 11, but we can change it to whatever works best for our site.
The access password: for security, we need to assign a password to connect to the network. We do this by assigning it in the line wpa_passphrase=LACONTRASENADEACCESS.

Now we must inform hostapd where the configuration is located. We do this by editing the :
sudo nano /etc/default/hostapd

… and adding in it the following line:
DAEMON_CONF=



Moment 6: Start the services
Before restarting our Pi, we must enable the services to run whenever we turn it on.
To do this, type the following in the terminal:
sudo systemctl unmask hostapd
sudo systemctl enable hostapd
sudo systemctl start hostapd

sudo systemctl unmask dnsmasq
sudo systemctl enable dnsmasq
sudo systemctl start dnsmasq


… and finally, we restart the Pi to make our first test.
sudo reboot now



Moment 7: Make a first test
  
From another computer or phone, search in the wireless networks for the network we just created, in our case SOLEVOLTAJE and connect to it.
If you check the network settings, you should see that the assigned IP address must be in the range we selected in the dnsmasq configuration . In our case, the device is assigned the IP 192.168.10.143.
  


Step 8: You can now share the wired connection
  
At this point, those who connect to our access point will be able to see the files and services that we have configured on our Raspberry Pi. If you want to share the wired Internet connection through the wireless network continue with the following steps.


Step 9: Forward traffic to the wired connection
  
It is necessary that our system forwards the traffic from the wireless interface to the wired one, in order to share the connection. At this point, we have to edit the file:
sudo nano /etc/sysctl.conf

In the contents of this, we look for the line that says #net.ipv4.ip_forward=1 and remove the # at the beginning to indicate that we want to activate this guideline. Once this modification is done, save the file and continue with the next step.


Step 10: Finally, secure the Firewall
  
We are now in the last step of the configuration. Here we have to tell the Firewall to allow the transit of network traffic between the wireless and wired interfaces, for this, we enter these commands in our terminal:
sudo iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o eth0 -j MASQUERADE
sudo iptables -A FORWARD -i eth0 -o wlan0 -m state --state RELATED,ESTABLISHED -j ACCEPT
sudo iptables -A FORWARD -i wlan0 -o eth0 -j ACCEPT

At this point, we should already have internet on our wireless clients! However, we need to make sure that these changes are not lost when we reboot our Pi. To do this, we will save the configuration in a text file:
sudo sh -c



Moment 11: Now, with Internet!
  
After this long process, the clients connected to our Pi will be able to access the shared Internet connection from our Raspberry Pi… SUCCESSFUL!


Did you get tangled up in any of the steps? Tell us how to complete this solution to make it clearer.
How do you know if this solution works?
With this recipe, you can set up a portable Router, which is used to carry content on your [Raspberry Pi](sole-doc.tiddlyhost.com/#Raspberry Pi) and share it with the community, without the need for a constant Internet connection.
Also, if you have a wired connection, you can share it to make your SOLE sessions more powerful.
Why might this solution work?
Having a portable, low-power router allows us to easily bring our content to multiple locations where the Internet connection is not constant.
However, the number of clients our Pi can support is low. If you are going to connect more than 10 people at the same time, maybe the connection speed gets a little slow and, to solve this, you should look for a more powerful router.
If you have come this far, you have learned a lot of things that you can share with your community to improve connectivity conditions. Using the Internet in a group is a challenging experience, both in terms of technology and in terms of community. Doing SOLE is a way to use the Internet as a group to live better together.

Some organizations that support low-cost Internet
Welcome
Hi, I’m Belen. Although I didn’t write the original of this solution, I’m revising it today so you can understand it better. Sometimes we feel like we are alone, working against the tide. I would like you to know that it doesn’t have to be that way, that there are people and organizations that can help you. I hope this solution will show you possible ways forward.
What is it like to seek financial support in your community to connect to the Internet?
There are initiatives that seek to connect people who do not have access to the Internet, especially in rural, remote and low-income areas.
They offer funding programs and resources for local communities and organizations that are working to build and expand Internet infrastructure, such as community networks and complementary access solutions.
They also provide information on how to obtain low-cost Internet through government programs and non-profit organizations.
What are they good for?
Contacting some of them can lead you to get internet access for your community, at affordable prices and with guarantees of maintenance, training and sustainability that you can’t imagine right now… take the plunge!
What do you need?

A computer with a web browser and Internet connection.
A web translator like google translate, deepl, or an artificial intelligence to help you translate (you can type in the search engine “ia to translate texts”)
Patience and time to dedicate to the search, better if you do it with others.
A dose of courage to submit your application to one of the initiatives… you have all our encouragement! We did it this way.

How to do it?


Moment 1: Think of the best question you can ask the internet and dare to dive to find… you can make a SOLE!
In the case of Colombia, it can be something like “what initiatives connect rural, remote and low-income communities in Colombia to the internet?”, or “how to get subsidized internet in Colombia?”, or “what organizations connect communities to low-cost internet in Colombia?” be creative in the question to find varied answers!
You can also search the search engine suggestions to dive in and find more related information.
Be encouraged to contact the companies and programs suggested by the search engine.


Moment 2: In SOLE Colombia we know some low cost connectivity initiatives around the world, take a look, we encourage you to contact them!


mintic.gov.co/portal/715/w3-article-401110.html - “Connecting the unconnected” program by MINTIC and Colnodo
The “Connecting the unconnected” program is an initiative of the Colombian Ministry of Information and Communication Technologies (MinTIC), which seeks to bring Internet to rural areas and communities with little or no connectivity.
The Digital Centers are free Wi-Fi access points installed in strategic locations to facilitate Internet access in these areas.
Steps to access, according to the program’s website:

Locate a Digital Center: Digital Centers are located in rural areas and communities with poor connectivity. You can find information about their location on the MinTIC website.
Activate your device’s Wi-Fi: Turn on the Wi-Fi on your phone, tablet or other device you wish to connect.
Search for the “MinTIC Conecta” network: Your device will display the available Wi-Fi networks. Select the network named “Mintic Conecta”.
Fill in the requested data: You will be prompted to enter certain information to register. Complete the required fields.
Accept the terms and conditions: Carefully read the terms and conditions and, if you agree, accept them in order to connect.Done! Once you have completed the above steps, you will be able to use the Internet connection.



www.colnodo.apc.org/es/NOTAS/banda-de-900-mhz-para-las-comunidades-una-oportunidad-para-transformar-el-acceso-a-internet-en-zonas-rurales
In Colombia, access to the 900 MHz band for communities is being addressed through a public consultation led by the Ministry of Information and Communication Technologies (MinTIC) and the National Spectrum Agency (ANE).
The objective is to make the use of this band more flexible for community networks, especially in rural areas with little or no commercial network coverage.
Process and Participation:

Public Consultation: A public consultation has been opened so that organized communities, community networks and other interested stakeholders can express their interest and provide comments on the proposal.
Participation Form: An online form is available for communities to describe their situation, interests and suggestions on the use of the band.
Information and Documentation: The ANE has published documents and guidelines for the consultation, which are available for viewing and downloading.
Deadline: The public consultation is open until July 1, 2025.

Focus on Rural Areas:

The 900 MHz band, with its capacity for good coverage and penetration, is considered ideal for supporting connectivity in rural and remote areas.
It seeks to enable community networks to take advantage of this band to bring connectivity to places where there is no or limited commercial coverage.

Potential Benefits:

Community Connectivity: Facilitate internet access for rural communities through community networks.
Economic and Social Development: Boosting access to services such as telemedicine, virtual education and other opportunities through connectivity.
Community Empowerment: Community networks can generate experience and autonomy in managing their own networks.
Future Readiness: Experience with this band can pave the way for the adoption of more advanced technologies and services in the future.

Active Participation:
It is crucial that interested communities actively participate in the publicconsultation, expressing their needs, expectations and proposals for the use of the 900 MHz band. The participation of all stakeholders is essential to build a strategy that ensures fair and sustainable connectivity for all.
In summary, the 900 MHz band represents an opportunity for Colombian communities to access the Internet and improve their connectivity, especially in rural areas, through community networks.
The public consultation is the space for communities to express their needs and contribute to the construction of a public policy that recognizes the importance of the spectrum for social and economic development.


hwww.internetsociety.org/es/funding-areas/connecting-the-unconnected/ www.internetsociety.org/es/funding-areas/connecting-the-unconnected/

Provides funding to organizations that build and expand Internet networks in underserved areas, which can result in more affordable options for residents.
Supports the creation of community networks, which are often a cheaper alternative to commercial options.



nupef.org.br/programas/acesso
NUPEF.org, through its focus on community networks and affordable Internet access, can facilitate access to funding and resources to build or strengthen community Internet networks, as well as provide training to manage and maintain these networks.
It also promotes the creation of safe and inclusive virtual communities, empowering marginalized groups to use technology and advocate for their digital rights:

Can help you apply for grants and funding for community network projects, including building new access solutions or expanding existing ones, especially for marginalized and underserved populations.
Provides training and resources for community members to develop skills in building, managing and maintaining community networks.
If they already have a network, NUPEF can help strengthen it by improving infrastructure, upgrading technology and providing technical support to ensure its continued operation.
Promotes the creation of safe and welcoming online communities, where diversity is valued and users are protected from violence and abuse.
Works to enable excluded people to use and adapt the Internet and digital technology to their needs, including the development of fair and equitable solutions for universal access.
Seeks economic models that enable affordable and sustainable access to the internet, generating community value and promoting self-sufficiency.
Facilitates the exchange of knowledge and experiences between different communities and movements, promoting collective action for digital inclusion.



www.apc.org/
It is a network of civil society organizations, which helps people to access the internet where connectivity is unavailable or unaffordable.
It also supports local and grassroots groups to use technology to develop their communities and advance the defense and exercise of their rights.
It promotes government ICT policies that serve the interests of the people, especially in the contexts of the global South.


unconnected.org/

An initiative that seeks to connect people who do not have access to the Internet, especially in rural, remote and low-income areas.
They offer funding programs and resources for local communities and organizations that are working to build and expand Internet infrastructure, such as community networks and complementary access solutions.
They also provide information on how to obtain low-cost Internet through government programs and non-profit organizations.



www.highspeedinternet.com/




If you know of any other ways to get support for connecting your community to low-cost Internet, don’t forget to comment on this Solution so we can incorporate it. We also ask that if you find this solution outdated or misinformation, please let us know so that we can continue to research and bring this information to the ends of the earth.
How do you know if this solution works?
How it can help to have low cost internet:

Infrastructure funding: there are organizations that offer funding to organizations that build and expand internet networks in underserved areas, which can result in more affordable options for residents.
Information on subsidy programs: other organizations provide information on government and non-government programs that offer subsidies or reduced rates for Internet access for low-income people.
Community networks: Others support the creation of community networks, which are often a cheaper alternative to commercial options.
Resources for building networks: some others offer a toolkit for building and maintaining community networks, which can help reduce infrastructure costs.
Training for installation and maintenance of equipment and networks.
Strengthening the social fabric and links between the community and with the community of practice: usually initiatives include content and practice in digital rights, equity, community ties and human-to-human connection, which make the internet an excuse for more aware and connected communities.

Why might this solution work?
The continuous search for Internet Solutions has led us at SOLE Colombia to investigate and be curious to find the Partners that have helped us bring the internet to very remote places.
In that same way, you, yes, you, having access to this information, can be encouraged to explore relationships with people and organizations that can guarantee the right that you and your community have to access the internet wherever you are.
When people come together to get things done, the sky is the limit.

Welcome
Hi, I’m Manuela. I’m the accountant of SOLE Colombia and, although I don’t know much about technology, I’ve started to get a taste for tinkering and I’m learning a lot of things that keep getting me out of trouble.
What is it?
Internet connection is not a ghost that accompanies us everywhere… or maybe it is a bit of a ghost!
This is a way in which you can learn a little more about what the Internet is and how to know what is failing at any given moment, or how to improve your signal.
What is it good for?
Knowing how good your Internet connection is can give you clues to understand performance and troubleshoot possible problems.
For example, it will let you know if the speed you contracted with your cell phone or internet service is what you are getting… or if you are being throttled.
You can identify the areas of your community, or your home, where you have the best signal. This way you can know where the movie you are watching will hang up, or where you need to position yourself to best receive someone’s call.
You will be able to make decisions in case you need to reboot the router, or change the signal reception channel. Or determine if your modem needs to be changed.
By optimizing the signal, you will have a faster and more stable connection to be able to do SOLE or access certain contents that require a better signal.
What do you need?

Your device
Be connected to the Internet signal

How to do it?


Step 1: Take your cell phone and see if you have a mobile signal.
Look at the top corner of your cell phone. There you will find some mobile signal bars: If you see one or more bars, the phone is receiving a signal and reading your SIM card.


Step 2: How good is the connection?

  I have no mobile signal bars
  1 mobile signal bar
  2 mobile signal bars
  3 mobile signal bars



Step 3: What type of mobile connection do you have?
Look next to the mobile signal bars and you will see the type of signal you have. These letters indicate the speeds and technologies that carriers use to send you information.


Mobile connection types and what are they for?
G: Abbreviates a [GPRS](../../Conceptorio 12a2bd68c5b6808baf3be5e67cddb488/Conceptorio 1624106bff984c4590342afeae3e5e0d/GPRS (Servicio General de Paquetes Vía Radio)%20GPRS%2025a2bd68c5b6806cb09bd0f9bba9c44e.md) connection, the slowest of all technologies. It is a second generation or 2G network used to send text messages.
E: Abbreviates anEDGE connection , it is an improved version of GPRS, also called 2.5G, and is used to search the Internet.
3G: Called UMTS, it is a third generation or 3G network, designed for multimedia content.
H: It usesHSPA technology , an improved 3G, and is more than enough to access social networks or listen to music on the Internet.
H+: It is an evolved HSPA to watch online videos or download them faster.
4G: It is the technology also called LTE, it is considered as the fourth generation or 4G. The speed of this network reaches 100 Mbps download and 50 Mbps upload, what we call broadband, very fast!
5G: It is the fastest technology of all, for now, and it is up to 100 times faster than 4G. You need a phone that supports 5G to use it.

  G: text messaging only
  E: browsing web pages
  3G, H, H+: social networking, music and videos
  4G, LTE: video calls and HD videos



Step 4: Do a speed test
  


How do you know if this solution works?
If you are able to get as far as the speed test result and know how fast your Internet is going, you are on the right track. You already have the information about the characteristics of your connection.
Why would this solution work?
Now, you can reflect, is the contracted speed the same as the one I have on my device? If not, maybe it is time to ask yourself, is the speed I have enough for what I need it for?
These practical, but at the same time somewhat philosophical, questions can give you arguments to make more conscious decisions, maybe it is time to switch to a cheaper plan or complain to your service provider.
Maybe you can also make decisions about taking up a collection with your neighbors to pay for an internet for everyone (which would be much cheaper), or analyze your surroundings to look for places that have good internet and spend some time a day there.

Make better use of your Internet service options
Welcome
Hi, I’m Manu. I’m not an expert in technology, but I know how frustrating it is when the movie freezes or the video call cuts off. So, after doing some research, I found some tricks to improve the connection at home that I want to share with you.
What is leveraging bandwidth?
Leveraging the options of the internet connection service you have is related to using all the settings and tools available to optimize your online experience, in terms of performance, speed, security and data efficiency.
What is it for?
Did you know that in the Internet world there are two terms that are often confused? I’m talking about bandwidth and speed. Let’s break them down and I will give you some tips to get the most out of your bandwidth and speed, contracted in your home Internet service.
Bandwidth and Speed: What’s that?
Imagine that bandwidth is like a giant truckload of goods, so it can carry a lot of packets (data) at once. The bigger the truck, the more packets it can carry. But here comes the key: speed is the time it takes, for that truck, to reach its destination. So, even if you have a huge truck (high bandwidth), if it doesn’t go fast, the packets will be waiting!
In conclusion: A high bandwidth allows you to move a lot of data at the same time, but, if the speed is slow, that data will take a long time to arrive. And that’s what can frustrate us when we are trying to watch a video or make a video call!
What do you need?

Wi-Fi Internet service at home
Patience and curiosity

How to do it?


Moment 1: Use the network cable
If you can, connect your computer to your router with a network cable. This is like going from a truck to a high-speed train - the difference is impressive! The wired connection will give you maximum speed and stability.
  
Photo taken from Pexels, (2024).


Moment 2: Connect to 5GHz if You Use Wi-Fi
  
Screenshot taken by Manuela Cordoba, (2024).
If you can’t use cable, the next best option is to connect to the 5GHz band of your router. This is like having access to a faster lane on a highway: less traffic, more speed. Just keep in mind that it works best when you’re close to the router.


Moment 3: Don’t Forget 2.4GHz
If you’re a bit far from the router, and you see that the connection gets slow, switch to the 2.4GHz band. Although it’s a bit slower than 5GHz, it can be more reliable. Think of it as a rural road that’s always available, even if it’s not as fast.
![Photo taken from Google photos, (2024).](¿Cómo aprovechar mi ancho de banda 1372bd68c5b680adbf93d08f2c52b69e/WhatsApp_Image_2024-11-07_at_11.26.28.jpeg)
Photo taken from Google photos, (2024).


Moment 4: Adjust the Wi-Fi Channel
Sometimes, the connection feels slow because there are too many people in your neighborhood using the same Wi-Fi channel. Changing the channel can make your connection faster and smoother. It’s like moving your party to a place where there is less noise.
Go to Improve Your Router’s Signal to follow the step-by-step.


Moment 5: Keep Your Router in Shape
Finally, make sure your router is well placed and up to date. Place it in a ventilated place and away from other interfering devices. A well-maintained router is key to have a good connection.
  
Photo taken by Manuela Córdoba, (2024).


How to know if this solution works?
If you have checked your speed, network configuration and data consumption on your devices and they are consistent with the data in your contract with your service provider, you can be sure that you are getting the most out of your Internet service.
By following these steps, you will not only have a better understanding of your bandwidth and speed, but you will also be able to optimize your connection and enjoy your online activities without any problems.
Why would this solution work?
To ensure that you are getting the most out of your service, in addition to checking speed and bandwidth, you can test at different times of the day, sometimes speeds may vary according to general network saturation.
You can also monitor your data consumption, the data usage of the applications and programs you use and set some limits to make your consumption more consistent.
