Some organizations that support low-cost Internet
Content
Welcome
Hi, I’m Belen. Although I didn’t write the original of this solution, I’m revising it today so you can understand it better. Sometimes we feel like we are alone, working against the tide. I would like you to know that it doesn’t have to be that way, that there are people and organizations that can help you. I hope this solution will show you possible ways forward.
What is it like to seek financial support in your community to connect to the Internet?
There are initiatives that seek to connect people who do not have access to the Internet, especially in rural, remote and low-income areas.
They offer funding programs and resources for local communities and organizations that are working to build and expand Internet infrastructure, such as community networks and complementary access solutions.
They also provide information on how to obtain low-cost Internet through government programs and non-profit organizations.
What are they good for?
Contacting some of them can lead you to get internet access for your community, at affordable prices and with guarantees of maintenance, training and sustainability that you can’t imagine right now… take the plunge!
What do you need?

A computer with a web browser and Internet connection.
A web translator like google translate, deepl, or an artificial intelligence to help you translate (you can type in the search engine “ia to translate texts”)
Patience and time to dedicate to the search, better if you do it with others.
A dose of courage to submit your application to one of the initiatives… you have all our encouragement! We did it this way.

How to do it?


Moment 1: Think of the best question you can ask the internet and dare to dive to find… you can make a SOLE!
In the case of Colombia, it can be something like “what initiatives connect rural, remote and low-income communities in Colombia to the internet?”, or “how to get subsidized internet in Colombia?”, or “what organizations connect communities to low-cost internet in Colombia?” be creative in the question to find varied answers!
You can also search the search engine suggestions to dive in and find more related information.
Be encouraged to contact the companies and programs suggested by the search engine.


Moment 2: In SOLE Colombia we know some low cost connectivity initiatives around the world, take a look, we encourage you to contact them!


mintic.gov.co/portal/715/w3-article-401110.html - “Connecting the unconnected” program by MINTIC and Colnodo
The “Connecting the unconnected” program is an initiative of the Colombian Ministry of Information and Communication Technologies (MinTIC), which seeks to bring Internet to rural areas and communities with little or no connectivity.
The Digital Centers are free Wi-Fi access points installed in strategic locations to facilitate Internet access in these areas.
Steps to access, according to the program’s website:

Locate a Digital Center: Digital Centers are located in rural areas and communities with poor connectivity. You can find information about their location on the MinTIC website.
Activate your device’s Wi-Fi: Turn on the Wi-Fi on your phone, tablet or other device you wish to connect.
Search for the “MinTIC Conecta” network: Your device will display the available Wi-Fi networks. Select the network named “Mintic Conecta”.
Fill in the requested data: You will be prompted to enter certain information to register. Complete the required fields.
Accept the terms and conditions: Carefully read the terms and conditions and, if you agree, accept them in order to connect.Done! Once you have completed the above steps, you will be able to use the Internet connection.



www.colnodo.apc.org/es/NOTAS/banda-de-900-mhz-para-las-comunidades-una-oportunidad-para-transformar-el-acceso-a-internet-en-zonas-rurales
In Colombia, access to the 900 MHz band for communities is being addressed through a public consultation led by the Ministry of Information and Communication Technologies (MinTIC) and the National Spectrum Agency (ANE).
The objective is to make the use of this band more flexible for community networks, especially in rural areas with little or no commercial network coverage.
Process and Participation:

Public Consultation: A public consultation has been opened so that organized communities, community networks and other interested stakeholders can express their interest and provide comments on the proposal.
Participation Form: An online form is available for communities to describe their situation, interests and suggestions on the use of the band.
Information and Documentation: The ANE has published documents and guidelines for the consultation, which are available for viewing and downloading.
Deadline: The public consultation is open until July 1, 2025.

Focus on Rural Areas:

The 900 MHz band, with its capacity for good coverage and penetration, is considered ideal for supporting connectivity in rural and remote areas.
It seeks to enable community networks to take advantage of this band to bring connectivity to places where there is no or limited commercial coverage.

Potential Benefits:

Community Connectivity: Facilitate internet access for rural communities through community networks.
Economic and Social Development: Boosting access to services such as telemedicine, virtual education and other opportunities through connectivity.
Community Empowerment: Community networks can generate experience and autonomy in managing their own networks.
Future Readiness: Experience with this band can pave the way for the adoption of more advanced technologies and services in the future.

Active Participation:
It is crucial that interested communities actively participate in the publicconsultation, expressing their needs, expectations and proposals for the use of the 900 MHz band. The participation of all stakeholders is essential to build a strategy that ensures fair and sustainable connectivity for all.
In summary, the 900 MHz band represents an opportunity for Colombian communities to access the Internet and improve their connectivity, especially in rural areas, through community networks.
The public consultation is the space for communities to express their needs and contribute to the construction of a public policy that recognizes the importance of the spectrum for social and economic development.


hwww.internetsociety.org/es/funding-areas/connecting-the-unconnected/ www.internetsociety.org/es/funding-areas/connecting-the-unconnected/

Provides funding to organizations that build and expand Internet networks in underserved areas, which can result in more affordable options for residents.
Supports the creation of community networks, which are often a cheaper alternative to commercial options.



nupef.org.br/programas/acesso
NUPEF.org, through its focus on community networks and affordable Internet access, can facilitate access to funding and resources to build or strengthen community Internet networks, as well as provide training to manage and maintain these networks.
It also promotes the creation of safe and inclusive virtual communities, empowering marginalized groups to use technology and advocate for their digital rights:

Can help you apply for grants and funding for community network projects, including building new access solutions or expanding existing ones, especially for marginalized and underserved populations.
Provides training and resources for community members to develop skills in building, managing and maintaining community networks.
If they already have a network, NUPEF can help strengthen it by improving infrastructure, upgrading technology and providing technical support to ensure its continued operation.
Promotes the creation of safe and welcoming online communities, where diversity is valued and users are protected from violence and abuse.
Works to enable excluded people to use and adapt the Internet and digital technology to their needs, including the development of fair and equitable solutions for universal access.
Seeks economic models that enable affordable and sustainable access to the internet, generating community value and promoting self-sufficiency.
Facilitates the exchange of knowledge and experiences between different communities and movements, promoting collective action for digital inclusion.



www.apc.org/
It is a network of civil society organizations, which helps people to access the internet where connectivity is unavailable or unaffordable.
It also supports local and grassroots groups to use technology to develop their communities and advance the defense and exercise of their rights.
It promotes government ICT policies that serve the interests of the people, especially in the contexts of the global South.


unconnected.org/

An initiative that seeks to connect people who do not have access to the Internet, especially in rural, remote and low-income areas.
They offer funding programs and resources for local communities and organizations that are working to build and expand Internet infrastructure, such as community networks and complementary access solutions.
They also provide information on how to obtain low-cost Internet through government programs and non-profit organizations.



www.highspeedinternet.com/




If you know of any other ways to get support for connecting your community to low-cost Internet, don’t forget to comment on this Solution so we can incorporate it. We also ask that if you find this solution outdated or misinformation, please let us know so that we can continue to research and bring this information to the ends of the earth.
How do you know if this solution works?
How it can help to have low cost internet:

Infrastructure funding: there are organizations that offer funding to organizations that build and expand internet networks in underserved areas, which can result in more affordable options for residents.
Information on subsidy programs: other organizations provide information on government and non-government programs that offer subsidies or reduced rates for Internet access for low-income people.
Community networks: Others support the creation of community networks, which are often a cheaper alternative to commercial options.
Resources for building networks: some others offer a toolkit for building and maintaining community networks, which can help reduce infrastructure costs.
Training for installation and maintenance of equipment and networks.
Strengthening the social fabric and links between the community and with the community of practice: usually initiatives include content and practice in digital rights, equity, community ties and human-to-human connection, which make the internet an excuse for more aware and connected communities.

Why might this solution work?
The continuous search for Internet Solutions has led us at SOLE Colombia to investigate and be curious to find the Partners that have helped us bring the internet to very remote places.
In that same way, you, yes, you, having access to this information, can be encouraged to explore relationships with people and organizations that can guarantee the right that you and your community have to access the internet wherever you are.
When people come together to get things done, the sky is the limit.

es/inspire/gprs-servicio-general-de-paqu.title: GPRS (Servicio General de Paquetes Vía Radio) | GPRS (General Packet Radio Services)
es/inspire/gprs-servicio-general-de-paqu.content:
GPRS (Servicio General de Paquetes Vía Radio) | GPRS (General Packet Radio Services)
Fecha de creación: 30 de agosto de 2025 23:19
Autor(a): Belen Sevilla Morillo
R2025: revisado
idioma: english, español
Español
GPRS fue una tecnología clave que introdujo el concepto de transferencia de datos por paquetes en las redes móviles, sentando las bases para los servicios de datos móviles que hoy damos por sentados, y sigue siendo útil en aplicaciones donde la transferencia de datos no requiere alta velocidad.

Servicio de Paquetes Vía Radio: Significa que la información se divide en pequeños “paquetes” de datos, que se envían de forma independiente a través de la red.
GPRS es un protocolo de comunicación de datos que opera sobre las redes de telefonía móvil de segunda generación (2G), actuando como una mejora de la tecnología GSM.
En lugar de usar un canal dedicado y continuo para datos (como GSM), GPRS asigna los recursos de la red solo cuando se están enviando datos, lo que la hace más eficiente.

¿Para qué sirve?

Acceso a Internet y Datos Móviles: Permitió a los usuarios conectarse a internet desde sus dispositivos móviles, aunque con velocidades moderadas.
Mensajería Multimedia (MMS) y Correo Electrónico: Facilitó el envío y recepción de mensajes más complejos que los SMS.
Servicios de Localización: Se utilizó para proporcionar servicios de localización a través de la red móvil.
Alarmas de Seguridad: GPRS sigue siendo relevante en sistemas de alarmas, ya que permite la transmisión segura de señales de alarma sin depender de una línea telefónica fija.

English
GPRS was a key technology that introduced the concept of packet data transfer in mobile networks, laying the groundwork for the mobile data services we take for granted today, and it remains useful in applications where data transfer doesn’t require high speed.

General Packet Radio Service: Means that information is divided into small data “packets,” which are sent independently through the network.
2G Technology: GPRS is a data communication protocol that operates over second-generation (2G) mobile telephone networks, acting as an enhancement to GSM technology.
Packet Switching: Instead of using a dedicated and continuous channel for data (like GSM), GPRS allocates network resources only when data is being sent, making it more efficient.

What is it used for?

Internet Access and Mobile Data: Allowed users to connect to the internet from their mobile devices, although at moderate speeds.
Multimedia Messaging (MMS) and Email: Facilitated the sending and receiving of more complex messages than SMS.
Location Services: Was used to provide location services through the mobile network.
Security Alarms: GPRS remains relevant in alarm systems, as it allows secure transmission of alarm signals without depending on a fixed telephone line.

Bienvenida
Hola, soy Sanjay y una de mis grandes empresas es darle uso comunitario a los recursos que tenemos disponibles. Me gusta cacharrear, sí, pero también me interesan las maneras en las que los humanos nos coordinamos para vivir mejor juntos.
¿Qué es hacer una colecta para pagar el internet comunitario?
Esta solución recoge ideas sobre cómo recolectar dinero para pagar una conexión comunitaria, es decir, conseguir que una comunidad se ponga de acuerdo para sostener económicamente un bien al que se dará uso y disfrute comunes.
¿Para qué sirve?
Encontrar maneras de organizarnos para adquirir las cosas que mejoran nuestras condiciones de vida, es, a veces una tarea compleja.
Si tienes claro que necesitan Internet, pero no sabes cómo hacer para que la gente de tu comunidad te siga la idea, te respalde en el mantenimiento y sostenibilidad del contrato, o no sabes cuáles son los pasos a seguir para poder hacerlo juntos, en esta solución puedes encontrar orientaciones útiles.
¿Qué necesitas?

Una idea muy clara del para qué quieres recolectar el dinero.
Carisma, palabra y don de gentes para convencer a las personas de que participen en la colecta.
Orden para llevar las cuentas, manejar el dinero e informar a las personas que colaboran contigo del curso de la colecta y los estados de las cuentas.
Habilidades de comunicación para informar a los colaboradores del estado del servicio, las necesidades de mantenimiento o las incidencias. También para recibir sugerencias o tramitar las gestiones que requiera la formalización, o el mantenimiento, del servicio.

¿Cómo hacerlo?
Estas recomendaciones son relevantes a la hora de hacer colectas de dinero con fines comunitarios. No se siguen necesariamente en orden, ni son las únicas, pero creemos que te puedan ayudar.


Momento 1: Armemos un equipo, entre varios es más fácil
Busca compañeros para empezar esta campaña.
Cuando emprendemos proyectos por un bien común, es fácil conseguir aliados para poder distribuirnos responsabilidades. Cuando haces este tipo de iniciativas solo, rápidamente puedes cansarte y desistir, pero con otros este proyecto será más llevadero.
Define quién se encargará de qué, eso hará que el trabajo esté más organizado y puedas hacer seguimiento más fácilmente.


Momento 2: Demos un propósito a la colecta, que sea claro y que nos entusiasme
Es importante tener el tiempo para reflexionar y proyectarnos sobre lo que queremos hacer, ¿qué es eso que queremos conseguir? Recuerda, el dinero sólo es un medio para llegar a algo más grande e importante… eso se llama propósito.
En este caso ¿qué es eso que nos une en esta colecta, que nos inspira a movernos para conseguir los fondos? Cuando estés estableciendo el propósito de algún proyecto es momento de preguntarnos incansablemente el para qué, hasta que estemos convencidos.
Hacer SOLE es una gran manera de encontrar un propósito para la colecta, además de pagarlo entre todos, pueden aprender, dialogar y crear comunidades florecientes, usando el internet en grupo. Pagar el internet entre todos ¡permite usarlo para hacer SOLE, o para cualquier cosa que se les ocurra!
Por ejemplo:

¿Para qué queremos internet en un lugar de acceso público? Para que las personas de mi comunidad puedan aprender nuevas cosas que necesiten o que quieran aprender, conversar y dialogar con otras personas y comunidades en una Gran Conversación, y tomar acción de forma autoorganizada para vivir mejor juntos.
¿Para qué queremos que las personas de nuestra comunidad puedan aprender juntos? Para que no sea necesario depender exclusivamente de los espacios de aprendizaje y personas relacionadas con el sistema educativo, para darnos cuenta de que cualquier persona puede aprender cualquier cosa, usando internet. ¿Por qué en grupo? Porque ir solo a cualquier parte es un camino difícil, en cambio, cuando lo hacemos juntos, se hace mejor.
¿Para qué queremos que puedan conversar a través de internet? Interactuar con otras personas con el objetivo de aprender o de que otros puedan ser parte de nuestra vida siempre nos hace sentir mejor. Aprender juntos cuando hay otras personas que participan de nuestros hallazgos y con quienes podemos recorrer el camino juntos, nos hace sentir que lo que aprendemos trasciende y es más grande que nosotros. Si las personas conectamos unas con otras a través de internet es porque nos interesamos mutuamente y podemos acompañarnos, no estamos solos en el camino… ¿Quieres conectar con personas alrededor del mundo en tus sesiones de SOLE? ¡Echa un vistazo a La Nube de Abuelitas SOLE! Son personas voluntarias de todas partes del mundo, que se conectan a las sesiones de SOLE para acompañar, brindar cálido aliento, compartir, aprender y divertirse juntos.
¿Para qué queremos colaborar a que nuestra comunidad pueda florecer? ¡Para que tengamos todos una vida más feliz, completa y sabrosa!

¿Tiene sentido tener internet de acceso público en nuestra comunidad? ¡Por supuesto!


Momento 3: Identifiquemos a los posibles interesados en participar
¿A quiénes de nuestros vecinos les interesaría tener internet comunitario? ¿Qué interés podrían tener para aportar monetariamente a este proyecto? Así podemos traducir nuestro proyecto a sus posibles intereses.
Aquí tienes algunos ejemplos de SOLEros que se han auto-organizado para aprender juntos, usando internet:

Elainer, cuando uso SOLE para que los jóvenes de su comunidad aprendieran a hacer videojuegos.
Robinson, que usó SOLE para que su comunidad pudiera encontrar alternativas sostenibles a los cultivos tradicionales de su comunidad.
María, cuando, a través de SOLE, consiguió que sus alumnos tomaran responsabilidad de su propio proceso educativo y cambió la manera de investigar y aprender en su colegio.



Momento 4: Una historia, la mejor manera de comunicar una idea
Ahora, que ya sabemos a quiénes vamos a dirigir nuestra campaña, vamos a crear una historia. Recomendamos contestar cinco preguntas fundamentales: quién, qué, cuándo, dónde y por qué.
Acá va la nuestra:
En la comunidad de La Piche se cultiva una miel deliciosa. Todos en la comunidad trabajamos en oficios relacionados con la producción de su deliciosa miel: algunos tienen panales, otros recogen la miel, otros la comercializan, algunos fabrican productos relacionados…
Somos un grupo de jóvenes interesados en crear productos cosméticos naturales a base de miel y cera de abeja, pero no sabemos cómo empezar a fabricar esos productos, ni los instrumentos que necesitamos, ni los permisos que requerimos o cómo podríamos comercializarlos, etc. Queremos empezar por ¿cómo podemos fabricar un pintalabios de miel y cera de abeja?
¡Usando Internet podríamos encontrar respuestas a estas y otras Grandes Preguntas!
El plan de Internet más barato es 120,000 COP, nadie en la vereda podría pagarlo. Pero hemos pensado que, haciendo una coleta entre 12 personas o familias, podríamos pagar una mensualidad de 10,000 COP y poner el internet de banda ancha por fibra óptica en un lugar de fácil acceso para todos, como puede ser el hogar geriátrico, el salón comunal o la tienda de doña Adela que es el negocio que está abierto la mayor parte del tiempo y donde todos podríamos conectarnos. La conexión podríamos usarla todos, hasta los niños de la vereda, para hacer sus tareas.
Así, si le interesa y puede ser parte de esta colecta, ¡súmese a esta lista! ¡ya pronto podremos tener internet para nosotros!
Todos los gastos y pagos de los recibos los enviaré el primero de cada mes a un grupo de WhatsApp y por ahí podremos estar al tanto de cualquier novedad
¿Se suma a la causa?


Momento 5: Compra, comunica y organiza los gastos
Con el dinero recolectado solo tienes que hacer la compra.
Recuerda que ninguno de estos contratos tiene cláusulas de permanencia, así que, si no estás satisfecho con el servicio, puedes cancelarlo y pasarte a otro operador.
Es importante ser organizado con las cuentas y comunicar oportunamente los pagos y cualesquiera novedades, o inconvenientes, de manera inmediata a todos los involucrados.
Así, todos pueden hacerse corresponsables de cualquier decisión relativa a esta colecta y puedan asumir las responsabilidades o consecuencias entre todos.
Asegúrate de crear un flujo de comunicación con tus colaboradores, para poder comunicarse en ambas direcciones y solucionar ágilmente los problemas que puedan surgir.


¿Cómo saber si esta solución funciona?
Con esta solución se consigue organizar a los vecinos hacia un bien común, encarnado en el pago de un servicio, para aprovecharlo de manera colectiva y sacarle el mejor partido posible.
También se logra mejorar las condiciones de conectividad del lugar en que vivimos, haciéndolo un lugar donde se vive mejor.
¿Por qué podría funcionar esta solución?
Organizándonos para conseguir cosas nos hará llegar tan lejos como queramos.
En este caso, nos permite tener un internet compartido un punto de acceso público. Es importante medir muy bien el ancho de banda que ofrece el servicio a contratar. Así, podremos contratar un servicio lo suficientemente rápido y potente en relación con el número de personas que queremos vincular a esa conexión.
El siguiente paso sería cómo mejorar las condiciones de esta conectividad, sin un aumento significativo de los costos.

On the banks of the river, between rocks and streams, the community of La Guayana, nestled in the mountains of Anorí, Antioquia, lives surrounded by majestic nature and a territory that fills them with pride. However, that same geography, which gives them wealth and beauty, also isolates them from the digital world.
[20240624_SOLE+WLH_Sintonización_Antioquia_LaGuayana (3).MP4](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Anorí, Antioquia 1362bd68c5b680f9a370e408f806b3d5/20240624_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_LaGuayana_(3).mp4)
According to John and Yuli, young SOLE Ambassadors of the community, in order to connect to the Internet they have to walk almost 40 minutes from their homes, sometimes uphill, looking for a point where the signal can reach. In their own words, even in the best of cases the signal is weak and limited. Turn up the volume to hear them!
[Tuning Visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Anorí, Antioquia 1362bd68c5b680f9a370e408f806b3d5/20240624_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_LaGuayana_(167).4.mp4)
Tuning Visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).
[Tuning Visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Anorí, Antioquia 1362bd68c5b680f9a370e408f806b3d5/20240624_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_LaGuayana_(166).5.mp4)
Tuning Visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).
The situation began to change with the Sintonización Visits. During these meetings, we explained to the community how the Internet works and why connectivity is a challenge in their territory. We discussed the technical difficulties inherent to their mountainous terrain and the costs associated with infrastructure in such remote locations.
That day, the SOLE team and the community faced the challenge of installing an antenna and a rural kit, technology specially adapted for areas of difficult access. For hours, the connectivity solution was assembled and disassembled, and with the collaboration of the Ambassadors and other community members, strategic signal points were sought. After several attempts and a collective work of patience and effort, we were able to connect the router and antenna to a satellite signal source located about 30 meters away.
[Tuning visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Anorí, Antioquia 1362bd68c5b680f9a370e408f806b3d5/20240624_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_LaGuayana_(8)(1).mp4)
Tuning visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).
[Tuning visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Anorí, Antioquia 1362bd68c5b680f9a370e408f806b3d5/20240624_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_LaGuayana_(79).mp4)
Tuning visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).
Thanks to this cacharrero effort, and to the fact that the Ambassadors did not give up until they achieved it, the community now has a community connection point. Although it is not the most stable, they can now access the Internet without the need to travel long distances.
Listen to Yuli’s excitement as she declares herself an Internet Cacharrera in her community!
[Tuning Visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Anorí, Antioquia 1362bd68c5b680f9a370e408f806b3d5/20240624_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_LaGuayana_(166).6.mp4)
Tuning Visits in La Guayana, Anorí, Antioquia, (2024).
The best part is that the story doesn’t end there: the Ambassadors have led SOLE sessions in their community throughout the year, where they answer great questions using the Internet as a group. In doing so, they have brought the use of technology and computers to their community, and opened doors for their neighbors to connect with the world.
Discover the website they have created to tell the world about their community:

This story begins in 2023, when we arrived in Calle Larga, in Buenaventura. There we were, with our rural connectivity kit. The idea was simple: to give them a better Internet connection so they could use it in the SOLE (Self-Organized Learning Spaces) sessions.  That’s when we met her:
[Rosa Helena Mina, Tuning Visits in La Delfina, Buenaventura, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Buenaventura, Vall 25c2bd68c5b680389d77d3f1869a5e2e/20240611_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_LaDelfina87.3.mp4)
Rosa Helena Mina, Tuning Visits in La Delfina, Buenaventura, (2024).
Over time, Rosa Helena became the “cacharrera” and SOLE Ambassador of the community, always willing to learn and help others to solve any connection problem that arose. Here in this video she is telling us how, little by little, she was learning and discovering what she had to do to have a more stable Internet connection.
Rosa Helena got fully involved in the project, with her curiosity and desire to learn, she led SOLE sessions. In Calle Larga, they no longer only have Internet, but a space for young people and adults to learn using the Internet in a group.
![SOLE Festivals, Calle Larga, Buenaventura, (2023).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Buenaventura, Vall 25c2bd68c5b680389d77d3f1869a5e2e/20230327_SOLEWLH_VisitaReconocimiento_CalleLarga_029.heic)
SOLE Festivals, Calle Larga, Buenaventura, (2023).
![SOLE Festivals, Calle Larga, Buenaventura, (2023).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Buenaventura, Vall 25c2bd68c5b680389d77d3f1869a5e2e/20230327_SOLEWLH_VisitaReconocimiento_CalleLarga_021(1).heic)
SOLE Festivals, Calle Larga, Buenaventura, (2023).
It didn’t stop there. In 2024, Rosa Helena was encouraged to visit a neighboring community, La Delfina, to share what she had learned. She arrived there with all her enthusiasm, ready to help them install their own Internet and to motivate them to tinker, so that they themselves could keep it working. And that’s where she met Jefferson.
Jefferson is one of those young people who is not afraid to mess with cables, routers, antennas and anything that smells of technology. With Rosa Helena’s help, he also joined the hacking patch and became a new SOLE leader in La Delfina. Imagine the excitement: your own Internet and someone who knows how to maintain it!
To see Jefferson in action, turn up the volume and listen to what he has to say about cacharreo and what he has learned:
[Jefferson Balcazar, Tuning Visits in La Delfina, Buenaventura, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Buenaventura, Vall 25c2bd68c5b680389d77d3f1869a5e2e/20240611_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_LaDelfina66.1.mp4)
Jefferson Balcazar, Tuning Visits in La Delfina, Buenaventura, (2024).
[Jefferson Balcazar, Tuning Visits in La Delfina, Buenaventura, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Buenaventura, Vall 25c2bd68c5b680389d77d3f1869a5e2e/20240611_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_LaDelfina66.2.mp4)
Jefferson Balcazar, Tuning Visits in La Delfina, Buenaventura, (2024).
To tinker with the Internet you don’t need to be an expert, just curious and eager to solve a situation. This year Jefferson has led SOLE sessions in his community, bringing them closer and closer to the use of technology and improving Internet access. So much so that, at the SOLE Festivals, they made their own web page to tell the whole world about their community.
Thanks to the enthusiasm of Rosa Helena and Jefferson, now in La Delfina they not only have Internet, but a tool to create and share their own world. At the last SOLE Festival, they got together to create their own web page and now they share their history, their customs and even what they have learned in the SOLE sessions with other communities and the whole world.
padlet.com/ladelfinacomunidad/sole-la-delfina-mtzyd41u0eu9im0o

This is the best thing about technology: it’s not just about having the Internet, it’s about having a space to learn and create together. Rosa Helena and Jefferson are creating the future of the Internet!

Chalán is a municipality in the department of Sucre, Colombia. In this region, villages like Monte Bello, Rancho Rojo, and Alemania are using the internet in unique ways: connecting as a group to answer big questions, complete homework, watch movies, or simply share their stories with the world.
Since 2023, Yulieth Farasica has been a SOLE Ambassador who has driven significant change in her community by leading collaborative learning sessions. Additionally, this year she helped us install, teach, and promote internet sharing in her village, Alemania. Now, neighboring villages can also connect to the internet, improving communication and access to information.
Listen to Yulieth as she tells her story about learning from connecting the community:
[Yulieth Farasica, Vistas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).](../../../How did the internet improve in Chalán, Montes de  1f408291a419462989817363aac27111/20240710_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_MM_Chaln_(23).1.mp4)

This is how Alemania is now a meeting point for Monte Bello, Rancho Rojo, and other nearby communities. People now travel to use this connection, which has been installed and operational thanks to everyone’s efforts.
[Gabriel, Vistas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).](../../../How did the internet improve in Chalán, Montes de  1f408291a419462989817363aac27111/20240710_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_MM_Chaln_(10).mp4)
Gabriel, Vistas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).
Six ambassadors have now been trained in the SOLE methodology and have learned how the internet works and how to use their Jangala to share it with others!
Yulieth, Astrid, Yuranis, Johana, Celia, Maryuris, and Yolanda are changing the world. Thanks to their work, more children, youth, adults, and seniors in Chalán now have access to the internet. From neighboring villages like Monte Bello and Rancho Rojo, people come to Vda. Alemania to connect and become part of this network, which they themselves have created and sustained.

In 2023, the Dominguillo community began an unexpected transformation, thanks to a new opportunity for connection. It all began when, through the USAID Threading Lives and Hope program, implemented by the IOM, a device called Jangala arrived at the community public school library. This device provided, for the first time, stable internet access, which quickly became an invaluable resource for everyone.
Here, presenting the Jangala, or “Jang,” as they decided to call him, is Luis Miguel Mina—or Lucho, as we all know him—one of the SOLE Ambassadors we trained in 2023:
[Franki, Lucho y Mateo in Talleres de Inspiración -  Dominguillo, Cauca (2023).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Dominguillo, Cauca 1362bd68c5b6803d96d4ca2135943c9a/20230517_SOLEWLH_Tallerdeinspiracion_Dominguillo_01(2).mov)
Franki, Lucho y Mateo in Talleres de Inspiración -  Dominguillo, Cauca (2023).
![Talleres de Inspiración - Dominguillo, Cauca (2023).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Dominguillo, Cauca 1362bd68c5b6803d96d4ca2135943c9a/20230517_SOLEWLH_Tallerdeinspiracion_Dominguillo_04.heic)
Talleres de Inspiración - Dominguillo, Cauca (2023).
The device was installed in the library to facilitate SOLE (Self Organized Learning Environments) sessions, a methodology that invites participants to learn autonomously and collaboratively through Big Questions. With these tools in place, Dominguillo members not only explored topics of interest but also began to answer questions about their culture and traditions, uniting the community around shared knowledge and rediscovering their roots through the internet.
Listen to Luis Miguel Mina and Nancy Campo talk about this experience:
[Luis Miguel Mina and Nancy Campo
SOLE Ambassadors in Festivales SOLE Dominguillo, Santander de Quilichao (2023).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Dominguillo, Cauca 1362bd68c5b6803d96d4ca2135943c9a/20230913_SOLEWLH_Festival_Dominguillo_entrevista_01(1).mp4)
Luis Miguel Mina and Nancy Campo
SOLE Ambassadors in Festivales SOLE Dominguillo, Santander de Quilichao (2023).
Sin embargo, con el paso del tiempo la comunidad ya no pudo seguir utilizando la biblioteca del colegio para sus sesiones de SOLE . Para entonces, el impacto de esta conexión había sido tan profundo que los habitantes de Dominguillo no quisieron renunciar a ella. Convencidos de la importancia de tener un espacio comunitario para el aprendizaje y la conectividad, buscaron apoyo para crear su propio centro de conexión: el SOLE Lab de Dominguillo.
Y… ¿Adivinen qué? Juntos, trabajamos en el desarrollo del SOLE Lab, un espacio público en el que se instalaron sillas, mesas y computadoras y se restableció el acceso a Internet. Con el SOLE Lab, los habitantes de Dominguillo recuperaron la oportunidad de conectarse al mundo, continuar sus sesiones de SOLE y explorar nuevas formas de aprendizaje.
.jpg)
Enchufa tu SOLE Lab - Dominguillo,  Cauca, (2024).
.jpg)
Enchufa tu SOLE Lab - Dominguillo,  Cauca, (2024).
.jpg)
Enchufa tu SOLE Lab - Dominguillo,  Cauca, (2024).
.jpg)
Enchufa tu SOLE Lab - Dominguillo,  Cauca, (2024).
Thanks to this effort, Dominguillo not only improved its internet connection but also strengthened the community bond. Now, the SOLE Lab is a meeting place where residents continue to learn and share their knowledge.

The USAID and IOM Threading Lives and Hope program brought SOLE Colombia to El Agrado. Together, we have worked to bridge the digital divide by bringing internet access to isolated communities, giving connection a purpose: using the internet together to learn in a self-organized and autonomous way. Since 2023, Piendamó, Cauca, has been the center of this story of change.
Alexander García, the Junk Merchant Who Builds Bridges
It was in El Agrado that we met Alexander García, a young community leader with a curious and committed spirit. From the beginning, Alexander was enthusiastic about technology, and especially the internet. With SOLE’s support, we installed a connectivity solution and some computers in the community shelter, which soon became the learning and meeting center for his community.
![Festivales SOLE in El agrado, (2023).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Piendamó, Cauca 1372bd68c5b680198faecc5d6b596b91/20230330_SOLEWLH_VisitaReconocimiento_ElAgrado_003(1).heic)
Festivales SOLE in El agrado, (2023).

Festivales SOLE in El agrado, (2023).
![Alexander in Festivales SOLE - El agrado, (2023).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Piendamó, Cauca 1372bd68c5b680198faecc5d6b596b91/20230330_SOLEWLH_VisitaReconocimiento_ElAgrado_002(1).heic)
Alexander in Festivales SOLE - El agrado, (2023).
The Journey to the Misak Pisicatau Reservation
Alexander’s curiosity to understand how routers, antennas, and networks work quickly led him to become an expert. In a matter of months, he went from someone who didn’t care about technology to a “tinkerer.” This newly acquired skill has made him a bridge between his community and other neighboring communities, sharing his knowledge with others.
In 2024, Alexander joined us on a new mission: to bring internet to a neighboring Indigenous community in the Misak Pisicatau Reservation. Upon arrival, we conducted speed and signal tests, and it was Alexander who quickly discovered that no antenna could provide a stable connection in that mountainous region.
[Visitas de Sintonización SOLE, Piendamó, (2024)](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Piendamó, Cauca 1372bd68c5b680198faecc5d6b596b91/20240612_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Misak_Piscitau_Piendam32.mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización SOLE, Piendamó, (2024)
Good news is that the Reservation had a stable satellite internet connection, so we only had to install a router to make it more reliable. Listen to him talk about the time we properly installed a router!
[Visitas de SIntonización, Piendamó, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Piendamó, Cauca 1372bd68c5b680198faecc5d6b596b91/20240612_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Misak_Piscitau_Piendam50.4.mp4)
Visitas de SIntonización, Piendamó, (2024).
With his technical skills and passion for teaching, Alexander was the first to motivate the residents of the reservation to explore the possibilities of the internet and join the SOLE movement. With his support, we installed computers in the community shelter, and Alexander encouraged them to continue using Self-Organized Learning in their community. Thanks to his encouragement, the Misak Pisicatau community has now created its own website, a space where they share their traditions, culture, and knowledge with the world.
.jpg)
Visitas de Sintonización SOLE, Piendamó, (2024)

Visitas de Sintonización SOLE, Piendamó, (2024)
Alexander has transformed not only his own knowledge, but also that of entire communities. Now, on the Misak Pisicatau Reservation, fear of technology has become a tool to preserve their identity, share their cultural heritage, and jointly address big questions like Why don’t Big Data and Artificial Intelligence have an ethnic focus?

Visitas de Sintonización SOLE, Piendamó, (2024)
This is just one of the many stories that demonstrate the power of connectivity to open doors and connect worlds. We invite you to learn more about the activities this community has undertaken and the projects they’ve created on their website.
SOLE: Resguardo Piscitau

The following excerpts are a compilation of testimonies, images, and scenes about how group internet use in the municipality of San Juan Nepomuceno is transforming internet access for neighboring communities, such as San José del Peñón and La Haya.
First Stop
[Festivales SOLE, Montes de María, (2024).](../../../How did the internet improve in San Juan Nepomucen 2602bd68c5b680d8be2fc8497ed318f4/WhatsApp_Video_2024-10-31_at_10.58.46(1).mp4)
Festivales SOLE, Montes de María, (2024).
To reach San José del Peñón, you must cross seven rivers. You cross your fingers to avoid the rain, and you marvel at the majestic beauty of this land. It’s no coincidence that, upon arrival, a large sign proudly welcomes you: “San José del Peñón, magical, fertile, and powerful land.”
The geography of San José del Peñón, with its mountains and dense vegetation, prevents signals from nearby antennas from reaching the area. Installing a community connectivity solution was a challenge that required the efforts of the entire community. With the support and collective work, we managed to install, against all odds, our Rural Kit: a Yagi antenna and a router that now make it possible for the community to gather periodically to practice SOLE.
[Gabriel, Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).](../../../How did the internet improve in San Juan Nepomucen 2602bd68c5b680d8be2fc8497ed318f4/20240711_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_MM_SanJuandeNepomuceno_(14).mp4)
Gabriel, Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).
[ Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).](../../../How did the internet improve in San Juan Nepomucen 2602bd68c5b680d8be2fc8497ed318f4/20240711_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_MM_SanJuandeNepomuceno_(11)(1).mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).
Rafael Antonio García, a born and bred tinkerer from his community, tells us in his own words what it was like to get the antenna installed: Turn up the volume to hear his story!
[ Rafael Antonio en Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).](../../../How did the internet improve in San Juan Nepomucen 2602bd68c5b680d8be2fc8497ed318f4/20240711_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_MM_SanJuandeNepomuceno_(1).2_(1).mp4)
Rafael Antonio en Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).
To tinker, you don’t need to be an expert or have experience building networks, antennas, or cables. Like Don Rafael Antonio, you too can be encouraged to collaborate with others to create a common good.
Currently, the community of San José del Peñón, together with its community, has continued to do SOLE on its own, using the Internet as a group to investigate Big Questions such as: Why is water wet? Why don’t humans use 100% of our brains? Why is there fresh water and salt water? Why are children born without teeth?
.jpg)
SOLE led by women Ambassadors in Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María (2024).
.jpg)
SOLE led by women Ambassadors in Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María (2024).
.jpg)
SOLE led by women Ambassadors in Festivales SOLE, Montes de María (2024).
That’s not all. The San José del Peñón community also created its own website, where they can upload their products and services, share their traditions, games, and anything else they want to show the world about their community. Check it out!
SOLE: San José del Peñón
Second Stop:
Since 2023, we’ve built a super-close relationship with the La Haya community. This year, one of the SOLE Ambassadors from there joined as a SOLE Explorer to help us bring a connectivity solution she already knew to San José del Peñón. Mariana Fernández was our indispensable support in training new ambassadors in her municipality and successfully installing the connectivity solution in this new SOLE community.
Turn up the volume to hear what this experience was like in her own words, and how using the internet as a group has transformed her territory:
[Mariana Fernández, Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).](../../../How did the internet improve in San Juan Nepomucen 2602bd68c5b680d8be2fc8497ed318f4/20240711_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_MM_SanJuandeNepomuceno_(15).2.mp4)
Mariana Fernández, Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).
Thanks to community collaboration and the implementation of solutions like the Rural Kit, San José del Peñón and La Haya now have community internet access, facilitating both learning and cultural exchange in the Montes de María.

Have you ever imagined a place where an entire community could connect to the Internet, learn and create together? In El Tambo, Cauca, that dream was a shared need.
In this community, Internet connection in rural areas is very limited, and in the urban area, access is mostly private. A public space with Internet became essential for everyone to connect, work on their collective projects and strengthen their territory.
In 2023, thanks to our ADAPT Peace Building partners, we met the community of El Tambo and their community circles: the youth circle, the water circle and the women’s circle. These groups had been working for more than a year on peace building and strengthening the social fabric. From that first meeting, a deep connection was created. The circles quickly appropriated the SOLE methodology and saw the group Internet as a tool to achieve a collective dream: a community space with Internet connection. This is how the spark of the SOLE Lab was ignited in this community.
![Recognition, El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en El Tambo, Cauca 1362bd68c5b6802a8df0f2c8fd47097f/20231019_BOLT_SOLELAB_Reconocimiento_Eltambo_06(1).heic)

Recognition, El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).

Recognition, El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).
During 2024, the Ambassadors of El Tambo were trained in the SOLE methodology and, together with RUTA 4 Taller, the collective work and the hands of the community gave life to their own SOLE Lab: The Second Library of the Future in Colombia!
This is how one of the neighbors of the SOLE Lab in Barrio Obrero describes it:
[Enchufa Tu SOLE Lab in El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en El Tambo, Cauca 1362bd68c5b6802a8df0f2c8fd47097f/20240801_SOLEBOLT_SOLELAB_Enchufa_ElTambo__(27).5.mp4)
Enchufa Tu SOLE Lab in El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).
[Enchufa Tu SOLE Lab in El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en El Tambo, Cauca 1362bd68c5b6802a8df0f2c8fd47097f/20240801_SOLEBOLT_SOLELAB_Enchufa_ElTambo__(27).3.mp4)
Enchufa Tu SOLE Lab in El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).
The SOLE Lab is not an ordinary library. It is a meeting point where children, youth and adults explore, create, dream and learn together. With community Internet access and collaborative spaces, the SOLE Lab invites the community to turn ideas into actions, make collective decisions, enjoy self-organized group learning and, why not, even watch movies.
[Enchufa Tu SOLE Lab in El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).](
  
  
&t=1s)
Enchufa Tu SOLE Lab in El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).
Thanks to the SOLE Lab, the Internet connection in El Tambo has improved significantly. Today, anyone can come and enjoy a more stable and faster connection, allowing students, families and neighbors to connect, research and create together new ways to use the Internet.
Now the El Tambo community can communicate and create links with other SOLE Laberas communities and people around the world. With each connection, bridges of collaboration are built that strengthen the sense of belonging and collective learning, each participant in the Library of the Future is part of a global network of learning and transformation.
[Enchufa Tu SOLE Lab in Tambo, Cauca, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en El Tambo, Cauca 1362bd68c5b6802a8df0f2c8fd47097f/20240801_SOLEBOLT_SOLELAB_Enchufa_ElTambo__(46).mp4)
Enchufa Tu SOLE Lab in Tambo, Cauca, (2024).
Check out some of the activities that the community has promoted in this space:
.jpg)
El Convite, El Tambo, Cauca, (2024).
Today the SOLE Lab awaits us with open doors to continue building the future of the Internet together!

KM15 is the geographical point on the road that leads to the Puerto Valdivia district from the municipal seat. It is also the name of the community located there. Life in *Km15—*kilometer 15, as it sounds in Spanish—runs alongside the highway that connects it to the rest of the world… or not. If its geographical location is a metaphor for its digital situation: in many places the internet is an everyday occurrence, there it feels distant.
Community internet access was a dream for its inhabitants. Most relied on expensive data plans on their cell phones or satellite internet, options that are not always affordable and that limit their possibilities.
[Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Valdivia, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b6804c8ef7f8a9b077eebe/20240625_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_KM15_(2).1.mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).
As a result of their exposure to new ways of using the internet, the women of KM15, who had already experienced the power of using the internet in groups, were drivers of change through the USAID-run Spinning Lives and Hope program implemented by IOM and SOLE Colombia.
Their commitment to learning led them to tinker with their ideas to transform this reality. Accompanied by SOLE Colombia, and guided by their enthusiasm and dedication, we were able to install a Jangala device in the community booth: a space that, from one moment to the next, became the connection hub for KM15.
[Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Valdivia, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b6804c8ef7f8a9b077eebe/20240625_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_KM15_(39).mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).
[Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Valdivia, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b6804c8ef7f8a9b077eebe/20240625_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_KM15_(49).mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).
The donation of several computers completed the toolkit with which these Ambassadors can now lead SOLE sessions in their community, bringing their neighbors closer to learning, technology, and a world full of possibilities.
Today, the community booth is not only a meeting place, but also a place to share the internet and manage resources communally.
.jpg)
Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).
.jpg)
Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).
The story doesn’t end there. The Ambassadors now understand how the Internet works, why it’s important to manage it, and the difference in internet usage that can occur between watching a movie or sending a text message. They are now experts using computers and the Internet in groups.
[Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Valdivia, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b6804c8ef7f8a9b077eebe/20240625_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_KM15_(2).4.mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).
[Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improve in Valdivia, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b6804c8ef7f8a9b077eebe/20240626_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_KM15_(38).3.mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización, KM 15 - Valdivia, Antioquia, (2024).
Women are taking over internet use in Valdivia. Have you ever wondered why you pay what you do for your cell phone plan or home internet?

In the Altos del Tigre community, in the municipality of Cáceres, five community leaders are making something almost impossible a reality: improving internet access in their community.
Yadiris Vaquero, Luz Cenith Acevedo, Kenia Yepes, Blanca Ofir Moreno, and David Ojeda, SOLE Ambassadors from their community, have been working for some time to ensure that internet access ceases to be a hidden treasure in their area. Because yes, in Cáceres, as in many places throughout Colombia, connection has always been a luxury.
This year, however, something changed. Starting with the Tuning Visit back in May, the Ambassadors and other community members took the opportunity to learn together how the internet works and why, specifically in Cáceres, getting a signal was a challenge. The answer? Basically, because there are no antennas for miles around and the telecommunications infrastructure is minimal.
But this didn’t discourage them. On the contrary, they got to work. They assessed the situation, looked for solutions, and, with the program’s support, found the ideal option for them: a Jangala device. This small but powerful device makes it possible to connect communities in hard-to-reach areas, and for the residents of Cáceres, it was like a gateway to a new world.
[Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improved in Cáceres, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b68058aac3cb67800ab59f/20240627_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_AltosdelTigre_(24).mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).
[Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improved in Cáceres, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b68058aac3cb67800ab59f/20240627_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_AltosdelTigre_(25).2.mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).
Thus, thanks to Jangala and the efforts of the SOLE Ambassadors, and all the people in the community who joined together to install this solution, Cáceres now has Internet access at a community access point.
[Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improved in Cáceres, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b68058aac3cb67800ab59f/20240627_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_AltosdelTigre_(62).mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).
[Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improved in Cáceres, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b68058aac3cb67800ab59f/20240627_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_AltosdelTigre_(52).mp4)
Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).
And for many, this achievement means much more than “being connected”: it’s an opportunity to learn, to be informed, to stay up-to-date. Children, young people, and adults can now access information, participate in SOLE sessions, and, as they say, “answer those big questions that previously seemed like something out of this world.”
Listen to one of the local residents, who dared to put up the Jangala antenna with the full SOLE patch:
[Arnulfo, Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).](../../../How did the Internet improved in Cáceres, Antioqui 2602bd68c5b68058aac3cb67800ab59f/20240627_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_Antioquia_AltosdelTigre_(105).5.mp4)
Arnulfo, Visitas de Sintonización en Altos del Tigre, Antioquia, (2024).
The work of Yadiris, Luz Cenith, Kenia, Blanca Ofir, and David Ojeda has marked a turning point in Cáceres. Today, thanks to their dedication and Jangala, the community not only has the Internet, but is transforming how it uses it, discovering, sharing, and creating many possibilities for their community.

La Estación and the La Esmeralda Indigenous Council are just a 15-minute motorcycle ride from each other. Both are neighboring communities in the Colombian municipality of Colosó, in the department of Sucre. Until recently, neither of these communities had a public space for group internet access. However, since 2023, they have ventured to use the connectivity solutions we installed together in their territory to promote Self-Organized Learning.
No one better than Mónica Vega, one of La Estación’s Star Ambassadors, to share the story of how these communities are transforming their access to information, connection, and education. Are you ready to listen? Don’t forget to turn up the volume!
[Mónica Vega, en Visitas de Sintonización, Montes de María, (2024).](../../../¿Cómo mejoró el Internet en Colosó, Montes de Marí 1302bd68c5b680259bbffb361b4d5867/20240709_SOLEWLH_Sintonizacin_MM_Colos_(35).mp4)

Even though Jangala wasn’t the right solution for this community, Monica and Gabriel, being the excellent “tinkerers” that they are, got to work, and nothing stopped them. Together, we explored other connectivity options and eventually installed an omnidirectional antenna and a router, with Monica’s help. Now, the La Esmeralda Ambassadors are empowering their neighbors to use the internet as a group.

Love, a desire for change and reconciliation? This is the New Mexico village, the Nasa Kiwe Tekh Kxsaw community located in Santander de Quilichao.


Using the SOLE methodology, the community asked themselves, “What happens in our bodies when we’re hugged?” A majority of them were women, using the internet and computers as a group. They laughed, chatted, and researched online, understanding things they’d never talked about before or had always assumed. Sharing their feelings and creating new knowledge. Together.

How the Internet works was the topic covered in a workshop format: submarine cables that carry the Internet signal through the ocean floor to the community, how to use it together, and what we can do with this vast network that unites us globally.
We installed a Jangala antenna and an omnidirectional antenna in a space where the community regularly meets to make decisions.

Today, the Nasa Kiwe Tekh Kxsaw community continues to ask Big Questions using the Internet and technology as a group.

Welcome
Hi, I’m Manuela. I’m the accountant of SOLE Colombia and, although I don’t know much about technology, I’ve started to get a taste for tinkering and I’m learning a lot of things that keep getting me out of trouble.
What is it?
Internet connection is not a ghost that accompanies us everywhere… or maybe it is a bit of a ghost!
This is a way in which you can learn a little more about what the Internet is and how to know what is failing at any given moment, or how to improve your signal.
What is it good for?
Knowing how good your Internet connection is can give you clues to understand performance and troubleshoot possible problems.
For example, it will let you know if the speed you contracted with your cell phone or internet service is what you are getting… or if you are being throttled.
You can identify the areas of your community, or your home, where you have the best signal. This way you can know where the movie you are watching will hang up, or where you need to position yourself to best receive someone’s call.
You will be able to make decisions in case you need to reboot the router, or change the signal reception channel. Or determine if your modem needs to be changed.
By optimizing the signal, you will have a faster and more stable connection to be able to do SOLE or access certain contents that require a better signal.
What do you need?

Your device
Be connected to the Internet signal

How to do it?


Step 1: Take your cell phone and see if you have a mobile signal.
Look at the top corner of your cell phone. There you will find some mobile signal bars: If you see one or more bars, the phone is receiving a signal and reading your SIM card.


Step 2: How good is the connection?

  I have no mobile signal bars
  1 mobile signal bar
  2 mobile signal bars
  3 mobile signal bars



Step 3: What type of mobile connection do you have?
Look next to the mobile signal bars and you will see the type of signal you have. These letters indicate the speeds and technologies that carriers use to send you information.


Mobile connection types and what are they for?
G: Abbreviates a [GPRS](../Conceptorio 2602bd68c5b681c182aed46fccc7c4ea/Conceptorio 2602bd68c5b68191afe2e809f2a2154d/GPRS (Servicio General de Paquetes Vía Radio)%20GPRS%202602bd68c5b681c4b651ecfe3b559103.md) connection, the slowest of all technologies. It is a second generation or 2G network used to send text messages.
E: Abbreviates anEDGE connection , it is an improved version of GPRS, also called 2.5G, and is used to search the Internet.
3G: Called UMTS, it is a third generation or 3G network, designed for multimedia content.
H: It usesHSPA technology , an improved 3G, and is more than enough to access social networks or listen to music on the Internet.
H+: It is an evolved HSPA to watch online videos or download them faster.
4G: It is the technology also called LTE, it is considered as the fourth generation or 4G. The speed of this network reaches 100 Mbps download and 50 Mbps upload, what we call broadband, very fast!
5G: It is the fastest technology of all, for now, and it is up to 100 times faster than 4G. You need a phone that supports 5G to use it.

  G: text messaging only
  E: browsing web pages
  3G, H, H+: social networking, music and videos
  4G, LTE: video calls and HD videos



Step 4: Do a speed test
  


How do you know if this solution works?
If you are able to get as far as the speed test result and know how fast your Internet is going, you are on the right track. You already have the information about the characteristics of your connection.
Why would this solution work?
Now, you can reflect, is the contracted speed the same as the one I have on my device? If not, maybe it is time to ask yourself, is the speed I have enough for what I need it for?
These practical, but at the same time somewhat philosophical, questions can give you arguments to make more conscious decisions, maybe it is time to switch to a cheaper plan or complain to your service provider.
Maybe you can also make decisions about taking up a collection with your neighbors to pay for an internet for everyone (which would be much cheaper), or analyze your surroundings to look for places that have good internet and spend some time a day there.

Think about when you go to a restaurant and order a cup of coffee. You, as a customer, ask or consult the waiter, and he goes to the kitchen and comes back some time later and serves you the cup of coffee ready, like a good server. You’re not quite clear on how he prepared it, but you know it’s a cup of coffee when you taste it. The Internet works in a similar way. Let’s see.
![SOLE Colombia, 2024.](../../../¿Cómo funciona el Internet 1362bd68c5b680c3b903ead1b7123665/20241101_Grafico__Como_funciona_el_Internet.png)
SOLE Colombia, 2024.
When you connect to the Internet and you have a question, what you do is to consult it from a cell phone or computer and you are communicating with many computers of other people or companies that store what you want to find.
The information you want to consult can be a web page, a video, a photo, a video call, a file or a message.  These are some of the digital file formats that are sent over the Internet
The cell phone, computer or tablet from which you connect to the Internet is called client.
The computer where the information you are consulting is stored is called the server.
How does the information travel through the Internet?
In order for the information sent by a server to reach your home, neighborhood, village or community, the client you use connects to the Internet. Let’s take, for example, your cell phone somewhere in Colombia and the response is on a server in Europe. This is the great adventure that your question takes.

How does your question travel through the Internet? SOLE Colombia, 2024.
Your cell phone connects by electromagnetic or wireless waves to one or more cell phone towers. Your question travels in the form of zeros “0” and ones “1” to one of those towers and down a cable that goes underground to some central wired location. It is then redirected to a seaport where that cable connects to a submarine cable. This goes under the ocean to the other continent and then out of the water to another cable point that carries your question to the server where your answer is located. The server receives your question and responds with the information it has stored - also in zeros “0” and ones “1” - and sends it back along the same route to your phone. And all this happens in a matter of milliseconds! It’s amazing, don’t you think?

The internet signal is transmitted through physical infrastructure such as fiber optic and copper cables, as well as through radio waves (Wi-Fi) and, to a lesser extent, via satellite or mobile networks (4G/5G). Data is converted into electrical or light pulses (bits) that travel through these media to their destination, using routers and other equipment to send and receive information.
Guided Media (cable):

Optical Fiber: Transmits data as light pulses through thin glass wires.
Copper (Coaxial and Twisted Pair): Uses metallic wires to carry electrical signals, as in ADSL connections.
Submarine Cables: Most global internet traffic travels through fiber optic cables laid under the ocean.

Wireless Media:

Wi-Fi: Uses radio waves to connect devices (like your phone or computer) to a router.
Mobile Networks (3G, 4G, 5G): Signals are transmitted through antennas and cell towers to provide internet access for mobile devices.
Satellite: Sends and receives signals to and from an orbiting satellite.

How does the process work?

Conversion to bits: When you send data (like an email), your computer converts it into pulses of electricity or light (bits).
Transmission: These bits travel through the physical infrastructure (cables, air, or space) to a network device.
Routing: Routers and other network equipment direct these bits along the most efficient path to their destination.
Receiving: At the receiving device, the bits are converted back into the original information that you can see or use.

(Fuente: es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medio_de_transmisi%C3%B3n)

Make better use of your Internet service options
Welcome
Hi, I’m Manu. I’m not an expert in technology, but I know how frustrating it is when the movie freezes or the video call cuts off. So, after doing some research, I found some tricks to improve the connection at home that I want to share with you.
What is leveraging bandwidth?
Leveraging the options of the internet connection service you have is related to using all the settings and tools available to optimize your online experience, in terms of performance, speed, security and data efficiency.
What is it for?
Did you know that in the Internet world there are two terms that are often confused? I’m talking about bandwidth and speed. Let’s break them down and I will give you some tips to get the most out of your bandwidth and speed, contracted in your home Internet service.
Bandwidth and Speed: What’s that?
Imagine that bandwidth is like a giant truckload of goods, so it can carry a lot of packets (data) at once. The bigger the truck, the more packets it can carry. But here comes the key: speed is the time it takes, for that truck, to reach its destination. So, even if you have a huge truck (high bandwidth), if it doesn’t go fast, the packets will be waiting!
In conclusion: A high bandwidth allows you to move a lot of data at the same time, but, if the speed is slow, that data will take a long time to arrive. And that’s what can frustrate us when we are trying to watch a video or make a video call!
What do you need?

Wi-Fi Internet service at home
Patience and curiosity

How to do it?


Moment 1: Use the network cable
If you can, connect your computer to your router with a network cable. This is like going from a truck to a high-speed train - the difference is impressive! The wired connection will give you maximum speed and stability.
  
Photo taken from Pexels, (2024).


Moment 2: Connect to 5GHz if You Use Wi-Fi
  
Screenshot taken by Manuela Cordoba, (2024).
If you can’t use cable, the next best option is to connect to the 5GHz band of your router. This is like having access to a faster lane on a highway: less traffic, more speed. Just keep in mind that it works best when you’re close to the router.


Moment 3: Don’t Forget 2.4GHz
If you’re a bit far from the router, and you see that the connection gets slow, switch to the 2.4GHz band. Although it’s a bit slower than 5GHz, it can be more reliable. Think of it as a rural road that’s always available, even if it’s not as fast.
![Photo taken from Google photos, (2024).](../../../../../Soluciona 1292bd68c5b681c6b5b5cec1700cc864/Solutions DB 1292bd68c5b681d1b87ccbb89a1b1d39/¿Cómo aprovechar mi ancho de banda 1372bd68c5b680adbf93d08f2c52b69e/WhatsApp_Image_2024-11-07_at_11.26.28.jpeg)
Photo taken from Google photos, (2024).


Moment 4: Adjust the Wi-Fi Channel
Sometimes, the connection feels slow because there are too many people in your neighborhood using the same Wi-Fi channel. Changing the channel can make your connection faster and smoother. It’s like moving your party to a place where there is less noise.
Go to Improve Your Router’s Signal to follow the step-by-step.


Moment 5: Keep Your Router in Shape
Finally, make sure your router is well placed and up to date. Place it in a ventilated place and away from other interfering devices. A well-maintained router is key to have a good connection.
  
Photo taken by Manuela Córdoba, (2024).


How to know if this solution works?
If you have checked your speed, network configuration and data consumption on your devices and they are consistent with the data in your contract with your service provider, you can be sure that you are getting the most out of your Internet service.
By following these steps, you will not only have a better understanding of your bandwidth and speed, but you will also be able to optimize your connection and enjoy your online activities without any problems.
Why would this solution work?
To ensure that you are getting the most out of your service, in addition to checking speed and bandwidth, you can test at different times of the day, sometimes speeds may vary according to general network saturation.
You can also monitor your data consumption, the data usage of the applications and programs you use and set some limits to make your consumption more consistent.

The more devices connected to the internet, the fewer MBs you’ll download. This happens because the speed is distributed across the number of connected devices.

Partnering with others who are more visible
Welcome
Hi, I’m Belen. I don’t know much about technology, but I love people and building relationships with them is something I’m very good at. I came to SOLE some time ago and have learned a lot about the power of people and what we can achieve when we join with others.
What is it like to partner with places that convene?
There are multiple people and organizations that can make your message reach farther and clearer, that can make your projects a pathway to transformation in your community. Knowing how to reach them and get their attention is a way to join forces to achieve great things.
What is it for?
Many times you want to count on your community to do things, or learn together, and you find it difficult to find people to join the movement, or you end up doing things with the same people.
With these recommendations you can find out how to approach others to support the call in your community.
What do you need?

Courage
Curiosity and listening skills
Something to take notes with

How to do it?


Moment 1: Define the purpose of the call, it will be easier to find allies.
The first thing is always the reason why you are going to do what you are going to do. If you intend to ally with others, you must be clear about the purpose of what you are going to do with them, only then, you will be able to focus the search for those who can help you to convene.
For example, if you are looking for people to build an antenna, would it be better to look for them in a hardware store, during the workday, or outside a kindergarten? Maybe it’s a better place where people come to find materials to build things, or tinker. The owner of the hardware store may be a better ally than the school teachers for the call to build an antenna.
Although you should not underestimate the talent of your community, you can prioritize the people and places you want to call with a clear ‘why’.
If you can, define your proposal in detail: is it an event, or a series of events? what do you need to have, or buy, or what do you need to equip your purpose with? do you need more people, or are you going to do it on your own?


Moment 2: Locate the conveners, who they are and what they do.
Look around you: in your neighborhood, in your community, in your locality… maybe in your own home you have allies!
Recognizing people and organizations with convening capacity, and allying ourselves with them, is strategic to achieve what we want.
Think about people and places where there is a flow of people, people who talk to the community, think about those who organize events. These types of actors will be relevant to convene… keep your purpose in mind so you can better see who has contact with the people you want to convene.
It is worth asking ourselves how we can build networks to successfully convene our activities. If you work on consolidating your abilities to join forces with others, you will start to see how it flows better and better.
  
Photo: SOLE Colombia


Moment 3: Read the interests of the conveners and how they resemble yours
Just as you want to organize a certain event, for example a SOLE, other people also have certain interests in the activities they want to promote.
Think about what appeals to each of these actors and how you can serve their interests as well as your own: including the other in a negotiated agenda can win you a long-term ally, not just a momentary collaborator.
For example, if your interest is to create the habit of doing SOLE in your community, you can partner with the Local Action Board. Understanding how using the Internet as a group to learn things together can meet the LAB’s objectives related to planning and executing community development projects, or digital rights guarantees for the community, is a nice way to open up the conversation about the activity you want to organize and how the LAB can support the convening of your event.


Moment 4: Choose who you want to do what with
Now that you have recognized the strategic actors to convene, and you know how to align their objectives with the ones you have, choose the one you feel best to work with for each of the objectives you have.
  
Photo: SOLE Colombia


Moment 5: Work on the invitation and the message you want to share.
Set out your ideas and prioritize them. Elaborate in depth each of the ideas you have and find the best way to present them to your ally is a way to practice the discourse and the way in which the information can better reach them.
You can make a script of possible questions and answers that may come up in the conversation. Put yourself in all possible scenarios, keep in mind the objections and problems your ally may have regarding your proposal. Having most of the scenarios contemplated, with a possible answer or alternative solution, will make your proposal look strong and consolidated.
Proposing a meeting to show your ideas in an orderly and calm manner is an excellent way to guarantee the attention of your potential ally. Agree with the person or persons who can give a ‘yes’ to your proposal, be punctual to that appointment and prepare the meeting well.
Work on the order in which you are going to present the information: a careful and orderly speech will let your interlocutor know that you are clear about what you want to do and will make him/her feel confident that he/she can count on you.
Don’t forget to make it very clear

what you are inviting your partner to do
what you will do and what you need from your partner
when you need them
for how long
who will be involved
how you will communicate with each other
how you will tell them what you have achieved because of the relationship between you.



Moment 6: Find out how you can make your proposal.
Some allies may be available to you anytime, anywhere. Others have a more formal way of operating, or need to make decisions by consensus. Still others need you to send a written proposal before you can talk to someone.
Approach the person, agency, business, or other partner and find out the best way to present your proposal. Follow the instructions and organize your time to be able to respond promptly to the requirements.


Step 7: Present your proposal and listen to your counterpart, the goal is to reach an agreement.
It’s time to demonstrate everything you have worked for! Trust in yourself and in the rigor with which you have prepared your proposal, we are sure that at this moment, with all the information you have, you will find the words to tell a good story that will hook your ally to do things together.
Once you’ve made your point, listen carefully to your potential ally. Possibly, there’s information you haven’t contemplated, so take note of the points that are weak or need to be expanded upon.
There may also be a time for negotiation: you and your ally should have a win-win scenario. Open your eyes and ears to anything that might have value for your purpose and strive to build a solid relationship.


Moment 8: Formalize commitments and get to work!
The moment your potential ally is clear on everything and so are you, it’s time to agree and make the next steps clear!
Write down what each of you is committed to and what the next steps are, it is always better not to forget anything.
Thank the people who have taken care of you, starting to work together is just the beginning and celebrating the agreements is a way to honor this new relationship.


How do you know if this solution is working?
You’ll know you’ve been successful in contacting places that convene the moment you start speaking the same language and find common ground in conversation.
For example, when someone who can call others pays attention to the proposal you make and wants you to meet their manager, or a colleague who can help you call people. Or also, when you find yourself adapting what you are going to say to the interest of the person who is listening to you, creating a space where the ideas start to belong to both of you.
If you exercise your listening skills, very soon you will be recognizing people with the ability to convene and seek to interest them.
If your purpose is to SOLE, you can start thinking of your Self-Organized Learning Space as a place where several allies can start to fulfill their purposes thanks to your space, or, the other way around, you can think of your ally’s space as a SOLE and benefit the people your ally convenes to learn to use the Internet as a group to live better together.
You can SOLE any activity or space!
Why would this solution work?
These recommendations are simple and limited. When you go looking for allies, much will depend on your communication skills.
Remember that you will not always be able to convince everyone to work with you, the important thing is to do it many times: ‘experience makes perfect’. And, in turn, listen to your intuition to start creating a ‘radar’ in you that will alert you to the people who can be your allies… be attentive!
